content.expert_insight: This is a critical internal instruction to ensure that legal terms align with operational realities. Without this check, Zebracorp could agree to restrictions that are impossible or highly detrimental to its business units.
content.justification: This is an internal process instruction to ensure operational alignment with contractual terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must involve relevant business units (CT/product line) to validate the practicality of proposed restrictions.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's proposed restrictions will be subject to internal review by Zebracorp's business teams.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the need for cross-functional collaboration in contract review.
content.text: In any event, the feasibility of such additional restrictions should in each case be confirmed with the respective CT/product line.

content.verbatim_text: We may require the right to use the licensed software/technology in e.g. for making adaptations by adding Zebracorp look and feel to the licensed software or a right to use certain software to provide technical support. In each case, we can define such use in the license grant so that the right to use is not too broad for the licensor to accept.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may need specific 'right to use' clauses for adaptations (e.g., branding) or technical support, defining these narrowly enough to be acceptable to the licensor.
content.expert_insight: This is a tactical approach to secure necessary rights without overreaching. By precisely defining the scope of 'use' for specific purposes, Zebracorp increases the likelihood of supplier acceptance while meeting its own operational needs.
content.justification: Provides strategic advice on how to define 'right to use' clauses to meet Zebracorp's needs while being acceptable to the licensor.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should identify specific 'use' cases (e.g., adaptation, support) and define them narrowly in the license grant.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will be more amenable to specific, narrowly defined 'right to use' clauses than broad, undefined ones.
content.source_insight: Suggests a balance between Zebracorp's needs and the supplier's comfort level regarding IP control.
content.text: We may require the right to use the licensed software/technology in e.g. for making adaptations by adding Zebracorp look and feel to the licensed software or a right to use certain software to provide technical support. In each case, we can define such use in the license grant so that the right to use is not too broad for the licensor to accept.

content.verbatim_text: As an example the license to adapt can, depending on our individual requirements, be narrowed down to read: “…a license to adapt the [Licensed Products] for the purposes of creating software application programming interfaces between the [Licensed Products] and the [ZEBRACORP Product]…”
content.plain_text: An example of narrowing an adaptation license is to specify it for creating APIs between the licensed product and a Zebracorp product.
content.expert_insight: This concrete example illustrates the 'narrowing down' tactic, showing how to transform a potentially broad and contentious right into a specific, functional permission that is more likely to be accepted by a licensor.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of how to implement the tactic of narrowing down a license right.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this type of specific language to secure adaptation rights without raising undue concerns from the licensor.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier is shown how a broad 'right to adapt' can be made acceptable through specific framing.
content.source_insight: Demonstrates the practical application of the 'define such use' tactic.
content.text: As an example the license to adapt can, depending on our individual requirements, be narrowed down to read: “…a license to adapt the [Licensed Products] for the purposes of creating software application programming interfaces between the [Licensed Products] and the [ZEBRACORP Product]…”

content.verbatim_text: The term right to reproduce which is commonly found in license grants is essentially the same as with the right to make copies and can be deleted if we do not require a right to make copies.
content.plain_text: The 'right to reproduce' is synonymous with 'right to make copies' and can be removed if Zebracorp doesn't need copying rights.
content.expert_insight: This is a contract simplification tactic. Removing redundant or unnecessary clauses reduces contract length and potential for misinterpretation, streamlining the negotiation process.
content.justification: Offers advice on simplifying contract language by removing a redundant or unnecessary clause.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can simplify its license agreements by removing 'right to reproduce' if 'right to make copies' is not needed or already covered.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier might encounter Zebracorp proposing to remove this term, which is generally non-contentious if the underlying right is not required.
content.source_insight: Highlights semantic redundancy in common license grant language.
content.text: The term right to reproduce which is commonly found in license grants is essentially the same as with the right to make copies and can be deleted if we do not require a right to make copies.

content.verbatim_text: The right to distribute is a key term in direct procurement and should always be included when Zebracorp is planning to further sell the software to its end customers.
content.plain_text: The right to distribute is essential in direct procurement and must always be included when Zebracorp intends to resell software to end customers.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental requirement for Zebracorp's business model. Without the right to distribute, Zebracorp cannot act as a reseller, which is a core part of its direct procurement strategy.
content.justification: States a critical requirement for Zebracorp's business model in direct procurement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure the 'right to distribute' is always included in agreements where it plans to resell software.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier must understand that Zebracorp's business model requires this right.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the importance of this right for Zebracorp's specific business operations.
content.text: The right to distribute is a key term in direct procurement and should always be included when Zebracorp is planning to further sell the software to its end customers.

content.verbatim_text: The right to distribute should include a right to use resellers and distributors or other sales channels in the sales interface. This is achieved by stating in the license grant that Zebracorp has the right to distribute “directly or indirectly”.
content.plain_text: The right to distribute should explicitly allow for indirect distribution via resellers and other sales channels, achieved by stating 'directly or indirectly' in the license grant.
content.expert_insight: This is a strategic detail that ensures Zebracorp's flexibility in its go-to-market strategy. Limiting distribution to 'direct' only would severely hamper its reach and efficiency, especially in global markets.
content.justification: Provides specific strategic advice on how to ensure broad distribution rights, including indirect channels.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should always seek 'directly or indirectly' distribution rights to maximize its sales channels.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier may push back on 'indirect' distribution, but Zebracorp needs this flexibility.
content.source_insight: Offers specific language ('directly or indirectly') to achieve the desired broad distribution right.
content.text: The right to distribute should include a right to use resellers and distributors or other sales channels in the sales interface. This is achieved by stating in the license grant that Zebracorp has the right to distribute “directly or indirectly”.

content.verbatim_text: The vendors may take objection to such indirect sales and it is sometimes beneficial to specify that Zebracorp will not be using any direct competitors of the software vendor as its sales channel.
content.plain_text: If vendors object to indirect sales, Zebracorp can offer a compromise by agreeing not to use the vendor's direct competitors as sales channels.
content.expert_insight: This is a common negotiation compromise. It addresses a legitimate concern of the supplier (protecting their competitive position) while still allowing Zebracorp to maintain its indirect distribution strategy.
content.justification: Offers a specific compromise tactic to address supplier concerns about indirect sales channels.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this compromise to secure indirect distribution rights, but must be mindful of its own competitive landscape.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier might find this a reasonable concession to protect their market position.
content.source_insight: Acknowledges potential supplier pushback and offers a practical solution.
content.text: The vendors may take objection to such indirect sales and it is sometimes beneficial to specify that Zebracorp will not be using any direct competitors of the software vendor as its sales channel.

content.verbatim_text: In order to further alleviate the concerns of the vendors, we can also specify in the contract that such resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality undertakings that are no less restrictive that those agreed between the vendor and Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: To ease vendor concerns, Zebracorp can contractually ensure its resellers/distributors are bound by confidentiality terms no less restrictive than those between Zebracorp and the vendor.
content.expert_insight: This is another effective compromise tactic. It assures the supplier that their confidential information will be protected down the distribution chain, addressing a key IP security concern without unduly restricting Zebracorp's business.
content.justification: Offers a specific contractual tactic to alleviate vendor concerns regarding confidentiality in indirect sales channels.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its reseller/distributor agreements include robust confidentiality clauses.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will appreciate this commitment to protecting their confidential information.
content.source_insight: Provides a practical way to build trust and address supplier IP concerns.
content.text: In order to further alleviate the concerns of the vendors, we can also specify in the contract that such resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality undertakings that are no less restrictive that those agreed between the vendor and Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: However, we should not agree to provide the licensor copies of any agreements pursuant to which we have granted sublicenses to the licensed software/technology to our end customers. Our agreements with the end customers are confidential and we are not authorized to disclose those without the end customers’ prior written authorization. Zebracorp assurances that the sublicense will be granted to the end customers in accordance with the terms agreed between Zebracorp and the licensor should be sufficient.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should refuse to provide licensors with copies of sublicense agreements with end customers due to confidentiality. Zebracorp's assurance of compliance should suffice.
content.expert_insight: This is a firm negotiation stance based on protecting Zebracorp's customer relationships and proprietary contract terms. Disclosing customer agreements is a significant breach of trust and potentially a competitive disadvantage.
content.justification: Provides a clear strategic position on protecting confidentiality of end-customer agreements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must protect the confidentiality of its end-customer contracts and resist demands for their disclosure.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's request for sublicense copies will be met with resistance due to Zebracorp's confidentiality obligations.
content.source_insight: Highlights a common supplier request that conflicts with Zebracorp's business practices and confidentiality duties.
content.text: However, we should not agree to provide the licensor copies of any agreements pursuant to which we have granted sublicenses to the licensed software/technology to our end customers. Our agreements with the end customers are confidential and we are not authorized to disclose those without the end customers’ prior written authorization. Zebracorp assurances that the sublicense will be granted to the end customers in accordance with the terms agreed between Zebracorp and the licensor should be sufficient.

content.verbatim_text: We should also not accept liability for any breach of the license terms by the end customers as such breaches are beyond our control.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not accept liability for end customers' breaches of license terms, as these are beyond its control.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy. Accepting liability for third-party actions that Zebracorp cannot directly control would expose it to undue and potentially massive financial risk.
content.justification: States a firm negotiation position to avoid accepting undue liability for third-party actions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must firmly reject any attempts to hold it liable for end-customer breaches.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's attempt to pass down liability will be resisted by Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the principle of not being liable for actions outside one's control.
content.text: We should also not accept liability for any breach of the license terms by the end customers as such breaches are beyond our control.

content.verbatim_text: As a compromise, we can propose in e.g. the following verbiage that basically puts an obligation on Zebracorp to monitor the usage by the end customer without accepting direct liability for the acts and omissions of the end customer: “[Zebracorp] will use commercially reasonable efforts to ensure that its sub-licensees comply with the respective license terms and will inform the [Licensor] promptly of any known violation, infringement or breach”.
content.plain_text: As a compromise, Zebracorp can propose language committing to commercially reasonable efforts to monitor sublicensee compliance and promptly inform the licensor of known breaches, without accepting direct liability.
content.expert_insight: This is an excellent compromise tactic. It demonstrates good faith and a commitment to protecting the supplier's IP without taking on unmanageable liability. 'Commercially reasonable efforts' is a standard that is defensible and manageable.
content.justification: Offers a specific compromise tactic and example language to address supplier concerns about sublicensee compliance without accepting direct liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can offer this compromise to show commitment to compliance without incurring excessive risk.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier might accept this compromise as it provides some assurance of compliance monitoring and reporting.
content.source_insight: Provides specific contractual language for a common negotiation point.
content.text: As a compromise, we can propose in e.g. the following verbiage that basically puts an obligation on Zebracorp to monitor the usage by the end customer without accepting direct liability for the acts and omissions of the end customer: “[Zebracorp] will use commercially reasonable efforts to ensure that its sub-licensees comply with the respective license terms and will inform the [Licensor] promptly of any known violation, infringement or breach”.

content.verbatim_text: Further compromise can be made by adding: “Zebracorp will affirmatively enforce the sublicensing terms for the software licensed under the sublicense and further agrees that it will assist [Licensor] in the manner reasonably requested by [Licensor] in [Licensor]’s pursuit of an action against any third party for breach of the respective sublicense”.
content.plain_text: A further compromise is for Zebracorp to agree to affirmatively enforce sublicense terms and assist the licensor in pursuing action against third-party breaches, if reasonably requested.
content.expert_insight: This deepens the compromise, offering active support in enforcement. It's a strong signal of commitment to IP protection, which can be a valuable concession in exchange for other desired terms, while still limiting Zebracorp's direct liability.
content.justification: Offers an additional compromise tactic and example language to further address supplier concerns about sublicense enforcement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can offer this to strengthen its position in negotiations, but must be prepared to follow through on enforcement and assistance.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier gains a commitment from Zebracorp to actively enforce terms and assist in legal actions.
content.source_insight: Builds upon the previous compromise, offering a more robust commitment to enforcement.
content.text: Further compromise can be made by adding: “Zebracorp will affirmatively enforce the sublicensing terms for the software licensed under the sublicense and further agrees that it will assist [Licensor] in the manner reasonably requested by [Licensor] in [Licensor]’s pursuit of an action against any third party for breach of the respective sublicense”.

content.verbatim_text: Any requirement to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to the end customer should be cleared with the respective Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.
content.plain_text: Any requirement to pass licensor's end-user license terms to Zebracorp's end customers must be approved by the relevant Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical internal instruction. Zebracorp's existing frame contracts with customers are paramount. Imposing a third-party's EULA could create legal conflicts, operational complexities, and customer dissatisfaction, hence the need for business unit approval.
content.justification: This is an internal process instruction to ensure business alignment and avoid conflicts with existing customer contracts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must involve its customer-facing teams before agreeing to pass through supplier EULAs, as it impacts existing customer relationships.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's request to pass through their EULA will be subject to internal review and likely resistance from Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Highlights the conflict between supplier EULAs and Zebracorp's pre-existing customer frame contracts.
content.text: Any requirement to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to the end customer should be cleared with the respective Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp preferred position when it comes to sublicensing terms is to state that we will sublicense to the end customers on same terms that we accept for our own software.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred position for sublicensing is to sublicense to end customers using the same terms it uses for its own software.
content.expert_insight: This is Zebracorp's ideal, streamlined approach, leveraging its established legal framework and customer relationships. It simplifies contracting and ensures consistency.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's preferred strategic position for sublicensing terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp aims to use its standard software terms for sublicenses to maintain consistency and efficiency.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will be asked to accept Zebracorp's standard terms for sublicenses.
content.source_insight: Defines Zebracorp's 'preferred position' as a starting point for negotiation.
content.text: Zebracorp preferred position when it comes to sublicensing terms is to state that we will sublicense to the end customers on same terms that we accept for our own software.

content.verbatim_text: Should this not be acceptable to the licensor, we can agree to say in e.g. that: “[Zebracorp] will sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its [End Customers] with license terms that are no less protective of the licensor’s rights than the license terms contained in this [Agreement].”
content.plain_text: If the licensor rejects Zebracorp's preferred terms, a compromise is to agree that sublicenses will have terms 'no less protective' of the licensor's rights than the main agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a common and effective compromise. It provides the supplier with assurance that their IP is protected without forcing Zebracorp to adopt the supplier's exact EULA, maintaining flexibility for Zebracorp.
content.justification: Offers a specific compromise tactic and example language when the preferred position is not accepted.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this language to satisfy supplier concerns while retaining control over its customer contracts.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier gains assurance of IP protection without dictating Zebracorp's exact sublicense terms.
content.source_insight: Provides a practical alternative to Zebracorp's preferred position.
content.text: Should this not be acceptable to the licensor, we can agree to say in e.g. that: “[Zebracorp] will sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its [End Customers] with license terms that are no less protective of the licensor’s rights than the license terms contained in this [Agreement].”

content.verbatim_text: Another equally acceptable compromise position may be found by adding in e.g. the following language: “[ZEBRACORP] may distribute and sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its customers provided that ZEBRACORP does not grant to any such customers any greater rights than [ZEBRACORP] has obtained from the [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: Another compromise is to state that Zebracorp can sublicense, provided it doesn't grant customers greater rights than it obtained from the licensor.
content.expert_insight: This is a similar, equally effective compromise that focuses on the scope of rights. It's a clear, concise way to ensure the supplier's rights are not diluted downstream, while still giving Zebracorp flexibility in its customer agreements.
content.justification: Offers an alternative compromise tactic and example language for sublicensing terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this language to ensure its sublicenses are within the bounds of its own license.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier is assured that their rights are not exceeded in downstream sublicenses.
content.source_insight: Offers a second, similar compromise option for sublicensing terms.
content.text: Another equally acceptable compromise position may be found by adding in e.g. the following language: “[ZEBRACORP] may distribute and sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its customers provided that ZEBRACORP does not grant to any such customers any greater rights than [ZEBRACORP] has obtained from the [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: In case the licensor required additional visibility on the license terms that we will be using with our end customers, we can agree to attach our standard Zebracorp End User License Terms to the agreement and state that “the sublicense will be granted on license terms that are substantially similar to those contained in the ZEBRACORP End User License Terms”.
content.plain_text: If a licensor demands more visibility on sublicense terms, Zebracorp can attach its standard EULA to the agreement, stating sublicenses will be 'substantially similar' to those terms.
content.expert_insight: This is a practical solution for transparency without full disclosure of every customer contract. 'Substantially similar' provides enough flexibility for Zebracorp while giving the supplier a clear understanding of the general terms.
content.justification: Offers a specific tactic to provide visibility to the licensor without compromising full confidentiality of individual customer contracts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use its standard EULA to provide transparency to licensors, but must ensure it is 'substantially similar' to what is actually used.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier gains visibility into the general terms of Zebracorp's sublicenses.
content.source_insight: Addresses the supplier's need for visibility while protecting Zebracorp's confidentiality.
content.text: In case the licensor required additional visibility on the license terms that we will be using with our end customers, we can agree to attach our standard Zebracorp End User License Terms to the agreement and state that “the sublicense will be granted on license terms that are substantially similar to those contained in the ZEBRACORP End User License Terms”.

content.verbatim_text: A copy of the Zebracorp End User License Terms is available to be obtained from any member of the Legal & Compliance team.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's standard End User License Terms are available from the Legal & Compliance team.
content.expert_insight: This is an internal process instruction, indicating where to source the official EULA document for use in negotiations or for internal reference.
content.justification: Provides an internal instruction on where to obtain a specific document.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp employees know where to find the official EULA for use in negotiations.
content.implication_supplier: N/A - internal instruction.
content.source_insight: Indicates the internal availability of a key document.
content.text: A copy of the Zebracorp End User License Terms is available to be obtained from any member of the Legal & Compliance team.

content.verbatim_text: When attaching the Zebracorp End User License Terms to our agreement with our licensor, we should only include the actual license terms and should remove any provisions that are not relevant to the actual license terms.
content.plain_text: When attaching Zebracorp's EULA to a licensor agreement, only include the actual license terms and remove irrelevant provisions.
content.expert_insight: This is a smart editing tactic. Removing extraneous clauses (e.g., payment terms, support SLAs) from the attached EULA ensures that the document focuses solely on the 'license terms' relevant to the licensor, preventing unnecessary scrutiny or negotiation points.
content.justification: Provides an internal instruction on how to prepare the EULA for attachment to a licensor agreement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should carefully redact its EULA before sharing it with licensors to avoid disclosing irrelevant or sensitive information.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will receive a streamlined version of Zebracorp's EULA focused on license terms.
content.source_insight: Offers practical advice for managing information disclosure when sharing internal documents externally.
content.text: When attaching the Zebracorp End User License Terms to our agreement with our licensor, we should only include the actual license terms and should remove any provisions that are not relevant to the actual license terms.

content.verbatim_text: Instead of enclosing our standard End User License Terms to the agreement, we can also expressly agree which minimum license terms need to be included in our sublicense agreement with the end customer. This approach would afford us greater flexibility in our contracting with our end customers (and as long as the list of such minimum terms remains customary and reasonable) and would be preferred over the inclusion of the Zebracorp End User License Terms.
content.plain_text: Instead of attaching its full EULA, Zebracorp can agree on a list of minimum required sublicense terms, which offers greater flexibility in customer contracting and is preferred.
content.expert_insight: This is a highly strategic and preferred approach. It gives Zebracorp maximum flexibility to tailor its customer contracts while still satisfying the supplier's need for core IP protection. It avoids the rigidity of a full EULA pass-through.
content.justification: Offers a preferred strategic approach for managing sublicense terms, emphasizing flexibility.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should advocate for agreeing on minimum sublicense terms rather than attaching its full EULA, to maintain contracting flexibility.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will be presented with a list of minimum terms, which they need to deem 'customary and reasonable'.
content.source_insight: Highlights a more flexible and preferred alternative to sharing the full EULA.
content.text: Instead of enclosing our standard End User License Terms to the agreement, we can also expressly agree which minimum license terms need to be included in our sublicense agreement with the end customer. This approach would afford us greater flexibility in our contracting with our end customers (and as long as the list of such minimum terms remains customary and reasonable) and would be preferred over the inclusion of the Zebracorp End User License Terms.

content.verbatim_text: Below is an example of a clause where Zebracorp agrees to such minimum license terms: “[Zebracorp] agrees that any sublicensing of the [Licensed Products] to its [Customers] shall be pursuant to an agreement between [Zebracorp] and each Customer, which agreement will at the minimum contain substantially the following license terms: (A) the [Licensed Products] may not be used by anyone other than [Customer] (and its employees, agents or contractors) for its own internal business purposes, (B) the licenses to the [Licensed products] are limited, nonexclusive and non-transferable (C) the [Customer] does not have any ownership or intellectual property rights to the [Licensed Products] other than the right to use such [Licensed Products] in accordance with agreement between [Zebracorp] and the [Customer], (D) the [Customer] has no right to use the [Licensed Products] except as set forth in the product documentation, and (E) the [Customer] has no right to reverse engineering, decompiling, disassembling of the [Licensed Products], all of which is expressly prohibited.”
content.plain_text: An example clause for minimum sublicense terms includes restrictions on use, non-transferability, no IP ownership, use only as per documentation, and prohibition of reverse engineering.
content.expert_insight: This example provides concrete language for the 'minimum terms' tactic. It shows how to protect core IP rights (no reverse engineering, no ownership transfer) while allowing Zebracorp flexibility in other aspects of its customer contracts.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of a clause detailing minimum sublicense terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this as a template for negotiating minimum sublicense terms with licensors.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier is shown a set of minimum terms that Zebracorp is willing to enforce downstream.
content.source_insight: Illustrates the practical application of the 'minimum license terms' tactic.
content.text: Below is an example of a clause where Zebracorp agrees to such minimum license terms: “[Zebracorp] agrees that any sublicensing of the [Licensed Products] to its [Customers] shall be pursuant to an agreement between [Zebracorp] and each Customer, which agreement will at the minimum contain substantially the following license terms: (A) the [Licensed Products] may not be used by anyone other than [Customer] (and its employees, agents or contractors) for its own internal business purposes, (B) the licenses to the [Licensed products] are limited, nonexclusive and non-transferable (C) the [Customer] does not have any ownership or intellectual property rights to the [Licensed Products] other than the right to use such [Licensed Products] in accordance with agreement between [Zebracorp] and the [Customer], (D) the [Customer] has no right to use the [Licensed Products] except as set forth in the product documentation, and (E) the [Customer] has no right to reverse engineering, decompiling, disassembling of the [Licensed Products], all of which is expressly prohibited.”

content.verbatim_text: In the majority of the cases, Zebracorp is not able to agree to such requests to modify our customer contracts. This is because, not all of our customer contracts contain such provisions and it is often next to impossible to amend our contract with our end customers merely to include certain language requested by an individual software vendor. The fact is that Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with our customers, and those contracts cannot be modified to suit the individual needs of each our vendor.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp generally cannot agree to modify its customer contracts to include vendor-specific liability limitations due to existing frame contracts and the impracticality of individual amendments.
content.expert_insight: This is a firm negotiation stance rooted in operational reality. Zebracorp's existing customer relationships and contractual framework take precedence. Attempting to modify every customer contract for each vendor is simply not feasible.
content.justification: Explains Zebracorp's inability to modify customer contracts for vendor-specific requests, providing a strong negotiation position.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must resist vendor demands to modify its customer contracts, citing operational impracticality and existing frame agreements.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's request to modify Zebracorp's customer contracts will likely be rejected.
content.source_insight: Highlights the rigidity of Zebracorp's existing customer contract framework.
content.text: In the majority of the cases, Zebracorp is not able to agree to such requests to modify our customer contracts. This is because, not all of our customer contracts contain such provisions and it is often next to impossible to amend our contract with our end customers merely to include certain language requested by an individual software vendor. The fact is that Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with our customers, and those contracts cannot be modified to suit the individual needs of each our vendor.

content.verbatim_text: If this requirement cannot be negotiated away, we can as a compromise, agree to inform our end customer of these limitations in writing in lieu of including these limitations in the agreement.
content.plain_text: If vendor-requested liability limitations cannot be negotiated away, Zebracorp can compromise by agreeing to inform end customers of these limitations in writing, rather than embedding them in the contract.
content.expert_insight: This is a pragmatic compromise. It addresses the vendor's desire for their limitations to be communicated to the end-user, without requiring Zebracorp to undertake the impossible task of amending its standard customer contracts.
content.justification: Offers a compromise tactic for communicating vendor liability limitations to end customers without modifying Zebracorp's contracts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this compromise to satisfy vendor demands while protecting its existing customer contract structure.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier receives assurance that their limitations will be communicated to the end customer.
content.source_insight: Provides a practical alternative when direct contract modification is not possible.
content.text: If this requirement cannot be negotiated away, we can as a compromise, agree to inform our end customer of these limitations in writing in lieu of including these limitations in the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances our licensors will ask that Zebracorp assumes liability for any breach of the sublicense terms and restrictions by its customers. This is not something that we can accept. The customers are independent third parties and Zebracorp cannot control the actions of its customers or give any guarantees of behalf of such parties. At best, we can contractually bind the customers to certain license terms and restrictions and report any violations to our licensor.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp cannot accept liability for customer breaches of sublicense terms, as customers are independent third parties beyond its control. At most, Zebracorp can contractually bind customers and report violations.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates a fundamental risk management principle: do not accept liability for actions you cannot control. It sets a clear boundary in negotiations, protecting Zebracorp from unmanageable risk.
content.justification: States a firm negotiation position against accepting liability for third-party actions, explaining the rationale.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must firmly reject any attempts to hold it liable for end-customer breaches, citing lack of control.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's request for Zebracorp to assume liability for customer breaches will be rejected.
content.source_insight: Reinforces the principle of limited liability for third-party actions.
content.text: In some instances our licensors will ask that Zebracorp assumes liability for any breach of the sublicense terms and restrictions by its customers. This is not something that we can accept. The customers are independent third parties and Zebracorp cannot control the actions of its customers or give any guarantees of behalf of such parties. At best, we can contractually bind the customers to certain license terms and restrictions and report any violations to our licensor.

content.verbatim_text: In the event of such requests, we can propose the below alternative wording instead: “If [Zebracorp] becomes aware of any material breach of any of the license terms and restrictions by its [Customer], [Zebracorp] shall promptly notify the [Licensor] thereof. In the event of the occurrence of any such material breach, the [Parties] shall consult in good faith on the next steps with respect to such breach and enforcement of such license restrictions”.
content.plain_text: As an alternative to assuming liability, Zebracorp can propose language where it agrees to notify the licensor of material breaches by customers and consult in good faith on next steps.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong compromise that balances the supplier's need for awareness and enforcement with Zebracorp's need to avoid direct liability. It demonstrates cooperation without accepting undue risk.
content.justification: Offers a specific alternative wording as a compromise to accepting direct liability for customer breaches.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this language to offer a cooperative solution without taking on direct liability.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier gains a commitment to be informed of breaches and to collaborate on enforcement.
content.source_insight: Provides specific contractual language for a common negotiation point.
content.text: In the event of such requests, we can propose the below alternative wording instead: “If [Zebracorp] becomes aware of any material breach of any of the license terms and restrictions by its [Customer], [Zebracorp] shall promptly notify the [Licensor] thereof. In the event of the occurrence of any such material breach, the [Parties] shall consult in good faith on the next steps with respect to such breach and enforcement of such license restrictions”.

content.verbatim_text: Note that all of the license rights should extend to the Zebracorp Group as a whole. The Zebracorp entity that signs the contract is not necessarily the same as the ordering Zebracorp entity. Moreover, the actual distribution and sublicensing or usage of the licensed products may be by a local Zebracorp entity as opposed to the entity that entered into the contract with the licensor. In each case the affiliates of Zebracorp should obtain the same rights as the signing Zebracorp entity.
content.plain_text: All license rights must extend to the entire Zebracorp Group, ensuring affiliates have the same rights as the contracting entity, regardless of which entity signs or uses the product.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical strategic requirement for a multinational corporation like Zebracorp. It ensures operational flexibility and avoids the need for multiple, fragmented licenses across different legal entities within the group.
content.justification: States a fundamental strategic requirement for license scope to cover the entire Zebracorp Group.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure all licenses cover its entire group to support global operations and avoid legal fragmentation.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier must be prepared to grant rights that extend to all Zebracorp affiliates.
content.source_insight: Highlights the complexity of licensing for large corporate groups with multiple legal entities.
content.text: Note that all of the license rights should extend to the Zebracorp Group as a whole. In each case the affiliates of Zebracorp should obtain the same rights as the signing Zebracorp entity.

content.verbatim_text: The license grants should also allow our dedicated contractors to make use of the license rights when in e.g. making permitted adaptations to the licensed product etc. or when distributing the licensed products.
content.plain_text: License grants should permit Zebracorp's dedicated contractors to use the licensed rights for permitted adaptations or distribution.
content.expert_insight: This is important for operational efficiency. Many companies rely on contractors for development, support, or distribution. Explicitly including them prevents bottlenecks and ensures seamless operations.
content.justification: States a strategic requirement for license scope to include dedicated contractors for operational purposes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to ensure its contractors can legally perform work related to the licensed products.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will be asked to extend certain rights to Zebracorp's contractors.
content.source_insight: Addresses the common practice of using contractors in business operations.
content.text: The license grants should also allow our dedicated contractors to make use of the license rights when in e.g. making permitted adaptations to the licensed product etc. or when distributing the licensed products.

content.verbatim_text: Where needed, we can remove some of the ambiguity surrounding the extent of the use by our contractors and revise this to read in e.g. as follows: “Any licenses granted to the [Licensee] shall also include the Affiliates of the [Licensee]. Any licenses granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall also extend to the subcontractors of [Licensee], but solely to the extent required for the purpose of enabling such subcontractors to perform work or provide services for [Licensee] (and its Affiliates) in support of this [Agreement], and not for the benefit of any third parties or for such subcontractor’s own benefit, and only while such subcontractors are providing such services to [Licensee] (and its Affiliates). For clarity, [Licensee] may not grant to its Affiliates and subcontractors any greater rights than [Licensee] has obtained from [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: To clarify contractor use, Zebracorp can propose language extending licenses to affiliates and subcontractors, but strictly for performing services for Zebracorp (and its affiliates) in support of the agreement, not for their own benefit or third parties, and only while providing such services. Affiliates and subcontractors cannot be granted greater rights than Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This detailed language is a sophisticated tactic. It addresses supplier concerns about uncontrolled third-party use by clearly defining the scope and limitations of contractor access, making it more palatable for the supplier while still meeting Zebracorp's operational needs.
content.justification: Offers specific contractual language to clarify and limit the scope of license use by contractors, addressing potential supplier concerns.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this precise language to ensure contractors have necessary rights without over-extending them, managing supplier risk.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier is provided with clear, limited terms for contractor use, which is more likely to be accepted.
content.source_insight: Provides detailed contractual language to resolve ambiguity and manage risk regarding contractor use.

Any licenses granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall also extend to the subcontractors of [Licensee], but solely to the extent required for the purpose of enabling such subcontractors to perform work or provide services for [Licensee] (and its Affiliates) in support of this [Agreement], and not for the benefit of any third parties or for such subcontractor’s own benefit, and only while such subcontractors are providing such services to [Licensee] (and its Affiliates). For clarity, [Licensee] may not grant to its Affiliates and subcontractors any greater rights than [Licensee] has obtained from [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: The license grant should give Zebracorp the necessary rights to each conceivable use of the licensed software/technology. Note that this is not necessarily reflected in the boilerplate license grants found in Zebracorp procurement contract templates, but those should be modified to reflect the actual needs for each case in hand.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's license grants must cover all conceivable uses of the software, and boilerplate templates should be customized to meet specific case needs.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial strategic directive. It emphasizes that boilerplate language is often insufficient and that a proactive, tailored approach is required for each licensing agreement to ensure full operational coverage and avoid future limitations.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's overarching strategic goal for license grants and the need for customization.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must actively review and customize license grants to ensure they meet all current and foreseeable business needs, rather than relying on standard templates.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier should expect Zebracorp to propose specific, tailored license terms rather than accepting boilerplate language.
content.source_insight: Highlights a potential gap between standard templates and actual business requirements.
content.text: The license grant should give Zebracorp the necessary rights to each conceivable use of the licensed software/technology. Note that this is not necessarily reflected in the boilerplate license grants found in Zebracorp procurement contract templates, but those should be modified to reflect the actual needs for each case in hand.

content.verbatim_text: In direct procurement contracts, it is important to make sure that the licenses also give Zebracorp the right to distribute/sublicense to its end customers and that such end customers obtain perpetual licenses (save where the license is specifically tied to a certain time frame).
content.plain_text: In direct procurement, licenses must grant Zebracorp the right to distribute/sublicense to end customers, and these end customers should receive perpetual licenses (unless time-limited by agreement).
content.expert_insight: This summarizes key, non-negotiable requirements for Zebracorp's direct procurement model. It ensures the continuity of its business by securing the necessary rights for its downstream customers.
content.justification: Reiterates critical strategic requirements for direct procurement contracts, essential for Zebracorp's business model.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize securing distribution/sublicensing rights and perpetual end-customer licenses in direct procurement.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier must understand these are fundamental requirements for Zebracorp's direct procurement business.

content.verbatim_text: In case we have not purchased a permanent license by paying a one-time non-recurring license fee, we may not require the license from the licensor to us to be either perpetual or irrevocable, but we can agree that the license is limited to the term of our mutual license agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Restrictions that are typically found in licensing agreement include the following type of clauses: “Except as otherwise agreed in this Agreement, Licensee is not entitled and shall not authorize or permit any third party to: (i) copy, alter or in any way modify the [Licensed Products] or create derivative works thereof without the prior written consent of the [Licensor]; (ii) decompile, disassemble, reverse compile, reverse assemble, reverse translate or otherwise reverse engineer the [Licensed Products] or in any other manner reduce the [Licensed Products] to source code or human perceivable form except to the extent the foregoing restrictions are not permissible under mandatory law; or (iii) use the [Licensed Products] as a service bureau, rental, timeshare or in a hosted environment. ”
content.plain_text: Common license restrictions include prohibiting copying, altering, modifying, creating derivative works, reverse engineering, and using the products as a service bureau, rental, timeshare, or in a hosted environment, unless otherwise agreed or mandated by law.
content.expert_insight: Provides concrete examples of standard restrictive clauses.
content.text: Restrictions that are typically found in licensing agreement include the following type of clauses: “Except as otherwise agreed in this Agreement, Licensee is not entitled and shall not authorize or permit any third party to: (i) copy, alter or in any way modify the [Licensed Products] or create derivative works thereof without the prior written consent of the [Licensor]; (ii) decompile, disassemble, reverse compile, reverse assemble, reverse translate or otherwise reverse engineer the [Licensed Products] or in any other manner reduce the [Licensed Products] to source code or human perceivable form except to the extent the foregoing restrictions are not permissible under mandatory law; or (iii) use the [Licensed Products] as a service bureau, rental, timeshare or in a hosted environment. ”

content.verbatim_text: The majority of the above restrictions are non-contentious.
content.plain_text: Most of these restrictions are generally accepted without dispute.
content.expert_insight: Indicates that these are standard clauses.
content.text: The majority of the above restrictions are non-contentious.

content.verbatim_text: However, it is recommended to state specifically that the above restrictions do not apply in cases where the parties have expressly agreed otherwise in the agreement (see underlined section in the above example).
content.plain_text: It is recommended to explicitly state that standard restrictions do not apply if parties have expressly agreed otherwise in the agreement.
content.expert_insight: Crucial for maintaining flexibility and ensuring that specific negotiated rights override boilerplate restrictions.
content.justification: To avoid conflict with specific rights Zebracorp may require (e.g., right to make copies, use in hosted environment).
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's specific business needs (like making copies or hosting) are not inadvertently restricted.
content.text: However, it is recommended to state specifically that the above restrictions do not apply in cases where the parties have expressly agreed otherwise in the agreement (see underlined section in the above example).

content.verbatim_text: This is necessary because we may have in e.g. agreed a right to make copies of the licensed software/technology.
content.plain_text: This is necessary because Zebracorp may have negotiated rights, such as making copies of the software.
content.expert_insight: Provides a reason for the previous guideline.
content.text: This is necessary because we may have in e.g. agreed a right to make copies of the licensed software/technology.

content.verbatim_text: In many cases we also require a right to use the licensed products in a hosted environment or a right to make the licensed products available to our customers as a service.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp often needs rights to use licensed products in a hosted environment or offer them as a service to customers.
content.expert_insight: Further justification for the need for exceptions to standard restrictions, highlighting Zebracorp's business model.
content.text: In many cases we also require a right to use the licensed products in a hosted environment or a right to make the licensed products available to our customers as a service.

content.verbatim_text: It may be worthwhile clarifying that our end customer (i.e. the industrial customer) may use the licensed software/technology to offer services to its subscribers through a hosted platform.
content.plain_text: Clarify that Zebracorp's end customers can use the licensed software/technology to offer services to their subscribers via a hosted platform.
content.expert_insight: Addresses a specific use case for end customers that might otherwise be restricted.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's end customers can fully utilize the licensed products for their business needs.
content.text: It may be worthwhile clarifying that our end customer (i.e. the industrial customer) may use the licensed software/technology to offer services to its subscribers through a hosted platform.

content.verbatim_text: This can be accomplished by adding in e.g. the following note: “The end-customer cannot use the [Licensed Products] for rental, timesharing, hosting or service bureau purposes, but such end-customer shall be entitled to use the [Licensed Products] to provide cloud-based or hosting services to its subscribers.”
content.plain_text: An example clause to clarify end-customer usage: "The end-customer cannot use the [Licensed Products] for rental, timesharing, hosting or service bureau purposes, but such end-customer shall be entitled to use the [Licensed Products] to provide cloud-based or hosting services to its subscribers."
content.expert_insight: Provides specific language for contract drafting.
content.text: This can be accomplished by adding in e.g. the following note: “The end-customer cannot use the [Licensed Products] for rental, timesharing, hosting or service bureau purposes, but such end-customer shall be entitled to use the [Licensed Products] to provide cloud-based or hosting services to its subscribers.”

content.verbatim_text: It may also be recommended to specifically state that the restrictions should not prevent Zebracorp managed services business.
content.plain_text: It is recommended to explicitly state that license restrictions should not hinder Zebracorp's managed services business.
content.expert_insight: Essential for Zebracorp to protect a core business activity.
content.implication_company: Safeguards Zebracorp's ability to offer managed services using the licensed products.
content.text: It may also be recommended to specifically state that the restrictions should not prevent Zebracorp managed services business.

content.verbatim_text: This can be accomplished by making the following or similar clarification: “For clarity, none of the foregoing shall restrict [Zebracorp] from using the [Licensed Products] on behalf of its[end-customers to provide managed services of such end-customer’s operations.”
content.plain_text: An example clause to clarify Zebracorp's managed services use: "For clarity, none of the foregoing shall restrict [Zebracorp] from using the [Licensed Products] on behalf of its [end-customers to provide managed services of such end-customer’s operations.”"
content.expert_insight: Provides specific language for contract drafting.
content.text: This can be accomplished by making the following or similar clarification: “For clarity, none of the foregoing shall restrict [Zebracorp] from using the [Licensed Products] on behalf of its[end-customers to provide managed services of such end-customer’s operations.”

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the nature of the licensed software/technology, there are also number of additional requirements and elements that the licensor may require in connection with granting us the licenses to its software/technology.
content.plain_text: Licensors may impose additional requirements based on the software/technology's nature.
content.expert_insight: Acknowledges that restrictions can vary significantly.
content.text: Depending on the nature of the licensed software/technology, there are also number of additional requirements and elements that the licensor may require in connection with granting us the licenses to its software/technology.

content.verbatim_text: The licensor may in e.g. specify maximum number of concurrent users, or require that their software is distributed and sublicensed only in connection with certain named Zebracorp products, or require that the software can only be used in certain defined platforms.
content.plain_text: Examples of additional licensor requirements include maximum concurrent users, distribution/sublicensing tied to specific Zebracorp products, or use on defined platforms.
content.expert_insight: Provides concrete examples of such additional requirements.
content.text: The licensor may in e.g. specify maximum number of concurrent users, or require that their software is distributed and sublicensed only in connection with certain named Zebracorp products, or require that the software can only be used in certain defined platforms.

content.verbatim_text: In most cases, such additional restrictions should be addressed in the product/pricing appendix instead of the license grant section as these restrictions can change over time and they are often tied to pricing.
content.plain_text: Most additional restrictions should be placed in the product/pricing appendix, not the license grant, because they are often tied to pricing and can change.
content.expert_insight: Practical advice for contract organization and flexibility.
content.justification: These restrictions are dynamic and often linked to commercial terms, making an appendix more suitable for updates.
content.implication_company: Allows for easier updates to commercial terms without renegotiating the core license grant.
content.text: In most cases, such additional restrictions should be addressed in the product/pricing appendix instead of the license grant section as these restrictions can change over time and they are often tied to pricing.

content.verbatim_text: In any event, the feasibility of such additional restrictions should in each case be confirmed with the respective CT/product line.
content.plain_text: Always confirm the feasibility of additional restrictions with the relevant Customer Team (CT)/product line.
content.expert_insight: Ensures that operational and business units are aligned with contractual terms.
content.implication_company: Prevents agreeing to restrictions that are impractical or detrimental to Zebracorp's business operations.
content.text: In any event, the feasibility of such additional restrictions should in each case be confirmed with the respective CT/product line.

content.verbatim_text: Most license grant clauses require the licensee to explicitly list those rights which the licensee requires.
content.plain_text: License grant clauses typically require licensees to explicitly list their required rights.
content.expert_insight: Highlights the proactive role of the licensee in defining rights.
content.text: Most license grant clauses require the licensee to explicitly list those rights which the licensee requires.

content.verbatim_text: In fact most Zebracorp in-licensing contract templates will say that: “There are no implied licenses granted under this [Agreement], and all rights, save for those expressly granted to [Zebracorp] hereunder, shall remain with the [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's in-licensing templates often state: "There are no implied licenses granted under this [Agreement], and all rights, save for those expressly granted to [Zebracorp] hereunder, shall remain with the [Licensor]".
content.expert_insight: Illustrates the "no implied licenses" principle, emphasizing the need for explicit grants.
content.text: In fact most Zebracorp in-licensing contract templates will say that: “There are no implied licenses granted under this [Agreement], and all rights, save for those expressly granted to [Zebracorp] hereunder, shall remain with the [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: A commonly used license grant in software license agreements will provide the following rights and licenses: right to use, make copies, to distribute and to sublicense.
content.plain_text: Common software license grants include rights to use, make copies, distribute, and sublicense.
content.expert_insight: Lists the typical bundle of rights in a software license.
content.text: A commonly used license grant in software license agreements will provide the following rights and licenses: right to use, make copies, to distribute and to sublicense.

content.verbatim_text: As for the right to use, it is often necessary to define in more detail what that right entails.
content.plain_text: The "right to use" often needs detailed definition.
content.expert_insight: Emphasizes the importance of specificity for this broad right.
content.text: As for the right to use, it is often necessary to define in more detail what that right entails.

content.verbatim_text: In direct procurement, Zebracorp generally does not require the right to use the software by itself but the focus is on the right to distribute and sublicense to our end customers.
content.plain_text: In direct procurement, Zebracorp's primary focus is on distributing and sublicensing to end customers, not internal use of the software itself.
content.expert_insight: Clarifies Zebracorp's typical business model and priorities for licensed software.
content.text: In direct procurement, Zebracorp generally does not require the right to use the software by itself but the focus is on the right to distribute and sublicense to our end customers.

content.verbatim_text: We may require the right to use the licensed software/technology in e.g. for making adaptations by adding Zebracorp look and feel to the licensed software or a right to use certain software to provide technical support.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may need the right to use licensed software for adaptations (e.g., adding Zebracorp branding) or for technical support.
content.expert_insight: Provides examples of specific "right to use" requirements for Zebracorp.
content.text: We may require the right to use the licensed software/technology in e.g. for making adaptations by adding Zebracorp look and feel to the licensed software or a right to use certain software to provide technical support.

content.verbatim_text: In each case, we can define such use in the license grant so that the right to use is not too broad for the licensor to accept.
content.plain_text: Define the "right to use" narrowly in the license grant to make it acceptable to the licensor.
content.expert_insight: Practical negotiation tactic to balance Zebracorp's needs with licensor's comfort.
content.implication_company: Facilitates agreement by addressing licensor concerns about overly broad rights.
content.text: In each case, we can define such use in the license grant so that the right to use is not too broad for the licensor to accept.

content.verbatim_text: As an example the license to adapt can, depending on our individual requirements, be narrowed down to read: “…a license to adapt the [Licensed Products] for the purposes of creating software application programming interfaces between the [Licensed Products] and the [ZEBRACORP Product]…”
content.plain_text: An example of narrowing an adaptation license: "...a license to adapt the [Licensed Products] for the purposes of creating software application programming interfaces between the [Licensed Products] and the [ZEBRACORP Product]..."
content.expert_insight: Provides specific language for tailoring adaptation rights.
content.text: As an example the license to adapt can, depending on our individual requirements, be narrowed down to read: “…a license to adapt the [Licensed Products] for the purposes of creating software application programming interfaces between the [Licensed Products] and the [ZEBRACORP Product]…”

content.verbatim_text: Often the key for the supplier is that our right to adapt their product is not too broad.
content.plain_text: Suppliers are often concerned about overly broad adaptation rights.
content.expert_insight: Explains the supplier's perspective, guiding negotiation strategy.
content.text: Often the key for the supplier is that our right to adapt their product is not too broad.

content.verbatim_text: The right to make copies is less relevant in today’s market where the software is delivered electronically and downloadable or accessible directly from the vendor’s website.
content.plain_text: The right to make copies is less relevant now due to electronic software delivery.
content.expert_insight: Reflects modern software distribution methods.
content.text: The right to make copies is less relevant in today’s market where the software is delivered electronically and downloadable or accessible directly from the vendor’s website.

content.verbatim_text: It is however, also possible that the software is provided through a master DVD/CD or that Zebracorp obtains a single copy on-premise which is then used to make further copies.
content.plain_text: The right to make copies might still be relevant if software is delivered via physical media or a single on-premise copy for further duplication.
content.expert_insight: Acknowledges exceptions where copying rights remain important.
content.text: It is however, also possible that the software is provided through a master DVD/CD or that Zebracorp obtains a single copy on-premise which is then used to make further copies.

content.verbatim_text: The term right to reproduce which is commonly found in license grants is essentially the same as with the right to make copies and can be deleted if we do not require a right to make copies.
content.plain_text: The "right to reproduce" is synonymous with "right to make copies" and can be removed if not needed.
content.expert_insight: Simplifies contract language by identifying redundant terms.
content.text: The term right to reproduce which is commonly found in license grants is essentially the same as with the right to make copies and can be deleted if we do not require a right to make copies.

content.verbatim_text: The right to distribute is closely associated with the right to sublicense.
content.plain_text: The right to distribute is linked to the right to sublicense.
content.expert_insight: Highlights the relationship between these two rights.
content.text: The right to distribute is closely associated with the right to sublicense.

content.verbatim_text: The right to distribute is a key term in direct procurement and should always be included when Zebracorp is planning to further sell the software to its end customers.
content.plain_text: The right to distribute is crucial in direct procurement and must always be included if Zebracorp intends to resell the software to end customers.
content.expert_insight: Essential for Zebracorp's reseller business model.
content.conditions: Zebracorp plans to resell software to end customers.
content.implication_company: Without this right, Zebracorp cannot legally resell the software, severely impacting its business.
content.text: The right to distribute is a key term in direct procurement and should always be included when Zebracorp is planning to further sell the software to its end customers.

content.verbatim_text: The right to distribute should include a right to use resellers and distributors or other sales channels in the sales interface.
content.plain_text: The distribution right should explicitly allow the use of resellers, distributors, and other sales channels.
content.expert_insight: Important for Zebracorp's multi-channel sales strategy.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp has flexibility in its sales and distribution network.
content.text: The right to distribute should include a right to use resellers and distributors or other sales channels in the sales interface.

content.verbatim_text: This is achieved by stating in the license grant that Zebracorp has the right to distribute “directly or indirectly”.
content.plain_text: Achieve this by including "directly or indirectly" in the distribution right in the license grant.
content.expert_insight: Provides specific contractual language.
content.text: This is achieved by stating in the license grant that Zebracorp has the right to distribute “directly or indirectly”.

content.verbatim_text: The vendors may take objection to such indirect sales and it is sometimes beneficial to specify that Zebracorp will not be using any direct competitors of the software vendor as its sales channel.
content.plain_text: Vendors might object to indirect sales; it can be beneficial to specify that Zebracorp won't use the vendor's direct competitors as sales channels.
content.expert_insight: Offers a negotiation strategy to address vendor concerns.
content.implication_supplier: Addresses potential competitive concerns for the vendor.
content.text: The vendors may take objection to such indirect sales and it is sometimes beneficial to specify that Zebracorp will not be using any direct competitors of the software vendor as its sales channel.

content.verbatim_text: Sales channels are commonly used in countries where Zebracorp does not have the necessary import licenses or in countries where Zebracorp does not have local presence.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp uses sales channels in countries lacking import licenses or local presence.
content.expert_insight: Explains the business rationale for indirect sales.
content.text: Sales channels are commonly used in countries where Zebracorp does not have the necessary import licenses or in countries where Zebracorp does not have local presence.

content.verbatim_text: In order to further alleviate the concerns of the vendors, we can also specify in the contract that such resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality undertakings that are no less restrictive that those agreed between the vendor and Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: To ease vendor concerns, specify that resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality terms no less restrictive than those between the vendor and Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: Another negotiation tactic to protect the vendor's IP.
content.implication_supplier: Provides assurance that their confidential information will be protected down the distribution chain.
content.text: In order to further alleviate the concerns of the vendors, we can also specify in the contract that such resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality undertakings that are no less restrictive that those agreed between the vendor and Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: However, having the supplier approve each distributor of Zebracorp, is more problematic and could be difficult or impossible to adhere to in practice.
content.plain_text: Requiring supplier approval for each Zebracorp distributor is problematic and often impractical.
content.expert_insight: Identifies an unacceptable and unworkable restriction for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Accepting such a clause would create significant operational hurdles and delays for Zebracorp's distribution network.
content.text: However, having the supplier approve each distributor of Zebracorp, is more problematic and could be difficult or impossible to adhere to in practice.

content.verbatim_text: As for the right to sublicense, the licensor may require additional protections on sublicenses, including requiring copies of any granted sublicenses, requiring the licensee to be responsible for compliance of sub-licensees and preventing the end users from sublicensing themselves.
content.plain_text: Licensors may seek additional sublicense protections, such as requiring sublicense copies, making the licensee responsible for sublicensee compliance, and prohibiting end-user sublicensing.
content.expert_insight: Outlines common licensor demands regarding sublicensing.
content.text: As for the right to sublicense, the licensor may require additional protections on sublicenses, including requiring copies of any granted sublicenses, requiring the licensee to be responsible for compliance of sub-licensees and preventing the end users from sublicensing themselves.

content.verbatim_text: The latter requirement does not often present any problems since our end customers are in most cases the actual end users of the licensed software/technology.
content.plain_text: Preventing end-user sublicensing is usually not an issue as Zebracorp's end customers are typically the actual end users.
content.expert_insight: Explains why one common restriction is often acceptable for Zebracorp.
content.text: The latter requirement does not often present any problems since our end customers are in most cases the actual end users of the licensed software/technology.

content.verbatim_text: However, we should not agree to provide the licensor copies of any agreements pursuant to which we have granted sublicenses to the licensed software/technology to our end customers.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not agree to provide licensors with copies of sublicense agreements with end customers.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical point regarding confidentiality and business practice.
content.justification: End customer agreements are confidential and cannot be disclosed without their prior written authorization.
content.implication_company: Protecting end customer confidentiality is paramount for Zebracorp's business relationships.
content.text: However, we should not agree to provide the licensor copies of any agreements pursuant to which we have granted sublicenses to the licensed software/technology to our end customers.

content.verbatim_text: Our agreements with the end customers are confidential and we are not authorized to disclose those without the end customers’ prior written authorization.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's end customer agreements are confidential and require customer authorization for disclosure.
content.expert_insight: Provides the legal and business reason for the previous guideline.
content.text: Our agreements with the end customers are confidential and we are not authorized to disclose those without the end customers’ prior written authorization.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp assurances that the sublicense will be granted to the end customers in accordance with the terms agreed between Zebracorp and the licensor should be sufficient.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assurance that sublicenses comply with Zebracorp-licensor terms should suffice, instead of providing copies.
content.expert_insight: Suggests a compromise position for negotiations.
content.text: Zebracorp assurances that the sublicense will be granted to the end customers in accordance with the terms agreed between Zebracorp and the licensor should be sufficient.

content.verbatim_text: We should also not accept liability for any breach of the license terms by the end customers as such breaches are beyond our control.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not accept liability for end customers' breaches of license terms, as these are beyond Zebracorp's control.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial risk management principle.
content.justification: Zebracorp cannot control the actions of independent third-party customers.
content.implication_company: Accepting such liability would expose Zebracorp to significant and uncontrollable financial and legal risks.
content.text: We should also not accept liability for any breach of the license terms by the end customers as such breaches are beyond our control.

content.verbatim_text: As a compromise, we can propose in e.g. the following verbiage that basically puts an obligation on Zebracorp to monitor the usage by the end customer without accepting direct liability for the acts and omissions of the end customer: “[Zebracorp] will use commercially reasonable efforts to ensure that its sub-licensees comply with the respective license terms and will inform the [Licensor] promptly of any known violation, infringement or breach”.
content.plain_text: A compromise for liability is to propose Zebracorp uses "commercially reasonable efforts" to ensure sublicensee compliance and promptly informs the licensor of known violations, without accepting direct liability for end customer acts/omissions.
content.expert_insight: Offers a balanced approach to address licensor concerns without Zebracorp taking on undue risk.
content.text: As a compromise, we can propose in e.g. the following verbiage that basically puts an obligation on Zebracorp to monitor the usage by the end customer without accepting direct liability for the acts and omissions of the end customer: “[Zebracorp] will use commercially reasonable efforts to ensure that its sub-licensees comply with the respective license terms and will inform the [Licensor] promptly of any known violation, infringement or breach”.

content.verbatim_text: Further compromise can be made by adding: “Zebracorp will affirmatively enforce the sublicensing terms for the software licensed under the sublicense and further agrees that it will assist [Licensor] in the manner reasonably requested by [Licensor] in [Licensor]’s pursuit of an action against any third party for breach of the respective sublicense”.
content.plain_text: Another compromise is for Zebracorp to agree to affirmatively enforce sublicense terms and assist the licensor in pursuing action against third-party breaches.
content.expert_insight: Provides an additional layer of compromise, showing Zebracorp's commitment to protecting the licensor's rights without direct liability.
content.text: Further compromise can be made by adding: “Zebracorp will affirmatively enforce the sublicensing terms for the software licensed under the sublicense and further agrees that it will assist [Licensor] in the manner reasonably requested by [Licensor] in [Licensor]’s pursuit of an action against any third party for breach of the respective sublicense”.

content.verbatim_text: Barring certain exceptional cases, we are not in a position to agree to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to our end customers.
content.plain_text: Except in rare cases, Zebracorp cannot agree to pass its licensor's end-user license terms to its end customers.
