content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental constraint due to Zebracorp's existing contractual framework.
content.justification: Zebracorp's sales are based on pre-existing frame sales contracts with fixed terms and conditions.
content.implication_company: Imposing licensor's EULAs would disrupt Zebracorp's established customer relationships and contract processes.
content.text: Barring certain exceptional cases, we are not in a position to agree to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to our end customers.

content.verbatim_text: This is largely due to the fact that our sales with our end customers are based on pre-existing frame sales contracts with already agreed and fixed terms and conditions.
content.plain_text: This is because Zebracorp's sales to end customers use pre-existing frame sales contracts with fixed terms.
content.expert_insight: Explains the practical difficulty of integrating external EULAs.
content.text: This is largely due to the fact that our sales with our end customers are based on pre-existing frame sales contracts with already agreed and fixed terms and conditions.

content.verbatim_text: Any requirement to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to the end customer should be cleared with the respective Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.
content.plain_text: Any requirement to pass licensor's end-user license terms to end customers must be approved by the relevant Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.
content.expert_insight: High-level internal coordination is required for such a significant deviation from standard practice.
content.conditions: Licensor requires passing their EULAs to Zebracorp's end customers.
content.implication_company: Ensures that any such deviation is strategically approved and understood across relevant business units.
content.text: Any requirement to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to the end customer should be cleared with the respective Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp preferred position when it comes to sublicensing terms is to state that we will sublicense to the end customers on same terms that we accept for our own software.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred sublicensing position is to sublicense to end customers using the same terms it uses for its own software.
content.expert_insight: Defines Zebracorp's ideal negotiation stance for consistency and efficiency.
content.implication_company: Streamlines contracting and ensures consistency with Zebracorp's existing legal framework.
content.text: Zebracorp preferred position when it comes to sublicensing terms is to state that we will sublicense to the end customers on same terms that we accept for our own software.

content.verbatim_text: Should this not be acceptable to the licensor, we can agree to say in e.g. that: “[Zebracorp] will sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its [End Customers] with license terms that are no less protective of the licensor’s rights than the license terms contained in this [Agreement].”
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp's preferred position is unacceptable, a compromise is to state that sublicenses will have terms "no less protective of the licensor’s rights than the license terms contained in this [Agreement]."
content.expert_insight: Provides a common and acceptable compromise for protecting licensor's IP without imposing their exact EULA.
content.text: Should this not be acceptable to the licensor, we can agree to say in e.g. that: “[Zebracorp] will sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its [End Customers] with license terms that are no less protective of the licensor’s rights than the license terms contained in this [Agreement].”

content.verbatim_text: Another equally acceptable compromise position may be found by adding in e.g. the following language: “[ZEBRACORP] may distribute and sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its customers provided that ZEBRACORP does not grant to any such customers any greater rights than [ZEBRACORP] has obtained from the [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: Another acceptable compromise is to state that Zebracorp may sublicense, provided it doesn't grant customers greater rights than it obtained from the licensor.
content.expert_insight: Offers an alternative compromise that similarly protects the licensor's rights.
content.text: Another equally acceptable compromise position may be found by adding in e.g. the following language: “[ZEBRACORP] may distribute and sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its customers provided that ZEBRACORP does not grant to any such customers any greater rights than [ZEBRACORP] has obtained from the [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: In case the licensor required additional visibility on the license terms that we will be using with our end customers, we can agree to attach our standard Zebracorp End User License Terms to the agreement and state that “the sublicense will be granted on license terms that are substantially similar to those contained in the ZEBRACORP End User License Terms”.
content.plain_text: If a licensor needs more visibility on sublicense terms, Zebracorp can attach its standard End User License Terms to the agreement and state that sublicenses will be granted on "substantially similar" terms.
content.expert_insight: Provides a method to satisfy licensor's visibility needs without full disclosure of specific customer contracts.
content.text: In case the licensor required additional visibility on the license terms that we will be using with our end customers, we can agree to attach our standard Zebracorp End User License Terms to the agreement and state that “the sublicense will be granted on license terms that are substantially similar to those contained in the ZEBRACORP End User License Terms”.

content.verbatim_text: A copy of the Zebracorp End User License Terms is available to be obtained from any member of the Legal & Compliance team.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp End User License Terms are available from the Legal & Compliance team.
content.expert_insight: Practical information on where to find relevant documents.
content.text: A copy of the Zebracorp End User License Terms is available to be obtained from any member of the Legal & Compliance team.

content.verbatim_text: When attaching the Zebracorp End User License Terms to our agreement with our licensor, we should only include the actual license terms and should remove any provisions that are not relevant to the actual license terms.
content.plain_text: When attaching Zebracorp End User License Terms to a licensor agreement, include only the actual license terms and remove irrelevant provisions.
content.expert_insight: Ensures clarity and avoids unnecessary information or potential conflicts.
content.text: When attaching the Zebracorp End User License Terms to our agreement with our licensor, we should only include the actual license terms and should remove any provisions that are not relevant to the actual license terms.

content.verbatim_text: Instead of enclosing our standard End User License Terms to the agreement, we can also expressly agree which minimum license terms need to be included in our sublicense agreement with the end customer.
content.plain_text: Instead of attaching full EULAs, Zebracorp can agree on a list of minimum license terms to be included in sublicense agreements.
content.expert_insight: Offers an alternative, more flexible approach to defining sublicense terms.
content.text: Instead of enclosing our standard End User License Terms to the agreement, we can also expressly agree which minimum license terms need to be included in our sublicense agreement with the end customer.

content.verbatim_text: This approach would afford us greater flexibility in our contracting with our end customers (and as long as the list of such minimum terms remains customary and reasonable) and would be preferred over the inclusion of the Zebracorp End User License Terms.
content.plain_text: This minimum terms approach offers greater flexibility with end customers (if terms are customary/reasonable) and is preferred over including full Zebracorp EULAs.
content.expert_insight: Explains the benefits and preference for the minimum terms approach.
content.text: This approach would afford us greater flexibility in our contracting with our end customers (and as long as the list of such minimum terms remains customary and reasonable) and would be preferred over the inclusion of the Zebracorp End User License Terms.

content.verbatim_text: Below is an example of a clause where Zebracorp agrees to such minimum license terms: “[Zebracorp] agrees that any sublicensing of the [Licensed Products] to its [Customers] shall be pursuant to an agreement between [Zebracorp] and each Customer, which agreement will at the minimum contain substantially the following license terms: (A) the [Licensed Products] may not be used by anyone other than [Customer] (and its employees, agents or contractors) for its own internal business purposes, (B) the licenses to the [Licensed products] are limited, nonexclusive and non-transferable (C) the [Customer] does not have any ownership or intellectual property rights to the [Licensed Products] other than the right to use such [Licensed Products] in accordance with agreement between [Zebracorp] and the [Customer], (D) the [Customer] has no right to use the [Licensed Products] except as set forth in the product documentation, and (E) the [Customer] has no right to reverse engineering, decompiling, disassembling of the [Licensed Products], all of which is expressly prohibited.”
content.plain_text: Example clause for minimum sublicense terms: "[Zebracorp] agrees that any sublicensing of the [Licensed Products] to its [Customers] shall be pursuant to an agreement between [Zebracorp] and each Customer, which agreement will at the minimum contain substantially the following license terms: (A) internal business use only by Customer (and its employees, agents or contractors), (B) licenses are limited, nonexclusive, non-transferable, (C) Customer has no IP ownership other than usage rights, (D) Customer's usage is limited to product documentation, and (E) reverse engineering, decompiling, disassembling is expressly prohibited."
content.expert_insight: Provides a concrete example of a minimum terms clause, detailing key protective provisions for the licensor.
content.text: Below is an example of a clause where Zebracorp agrees to such minimum license terms: “[Zebracorp] agrees that any sublicensing of the [Licensed Products] to its [Customers] shall be pursuant to an agreement between [Zebracorp] and each Customer, which agreement will at the minimum contain substantially the following license terms: (A) the [Licensed Products] may not be used by anyone other than [Customer] (and its employees, agents or contractors) for its own internal business purposes, (B) the licenses to the [Licensed products] are limited, nonexclusive and non-transferable (C) the [Customer] does not have any ownership or intellectual property rights to the [Licensed Products] other than the right to use such [Licensed Products] in accordance with agreement between [Zebracorp] and the [Customer], (D) the [Customer] has no right to use the [Licensed Products] except as set forth in the product documentation, and (E) the [Customer] has no right to reverse engineering, decompiling, disassembling of the [Licensed Products], all of which is expressly prohibited.”

content.verbatim_text: It is not unusual for the software vendors to also require that we will also expressly limit the vendors liability in our end customer contract by in e.g. adding following provisions to our end customer contract: “[XYZ] Corporation disclaims all warranties, whether express or implied. [XYX] Corporation shall have no liability towards the [Customer] “.
content.plain_text: Software vendors often require Zebracorp to expressly limit the vendor's liability in end customer contracts, such as disclaiming all warranties and liability towards the customer.
content.expert_insight: Describes a common request from licensors.
content.text: It is not unusual for the software vendors to also require that we will also expressly limit the vendors liability in our end customer contract by in e.g. adding following provisions to our end customer contract: “[XYZ] Corporation disclaims all warranties, whether express or implied. [XYX] Corporation shall have no liability towards the [Customer] “.

content.verbatim_text: In the majority of the cases, Zebracorp is not able to agree to such requests to modify our customer contracts.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp is generally unable to agree to requests to modify its customer contracts for vendor liability limitations.
content.expert_insight: States Zebracorp's firm position on this matter.
content.justification: Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with customers that cannot be easily modified for individual vendor needs.
content.implication_company: Protecting the integrity and consistency of Zebracorp's standard customer contracts is crucial.
content.text: In the majority of the cases, Zebracorp is not able to agree to such requests to modify our customer contracts.

content.verbatim_text: This is because, not all of our customer contracts contain such provisions and it is often next to impossible to amend our contract with our end customers merely to include certain language requested by an individual software vendor.
content.plain_text: Amending Zebracorp's customer contracts for individual vendor requests is often impossible due to existing frame contracts and varied provisions.
content.expert_insight: Explains the practical and contractual difficulties.
content.text: This is because, not all of our customer contracts contain such provisions and it is often next to impossible to amend our contract with our end customers merely to include certain language requested by an individual software vendor.

content.verbatim_text: The fact is that Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with our customers, and those contracts cannot be modified to suit the individual needs of each our vendor.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's existing frame contracts with customers cannot be modified for individual vendor needs.
content.expert_insight: Reinforces the inflexibility of Zebracorp's customer contracts.
content.text: The fact is that Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with our customers, and those contracts cannot be modified to suit the individual needs of each our vendor.

content.verbatim_text: If this requirement cannot be negotiated away, we can as a compromise, agree to inform our end customer of these limitations in writing in lieu of including these limitations in the agreement.
content.plain_text: If vendor liability limitations cannot be negotiated away, Zebracorp can compromise by agreeing to inform end customers of these limitations in writing, instead of amending the contract.
content.expert_insight: Offers a practical alternative when direct contract modification is impossible.
content.text: If this requirement cannot be negotiated away, we can as a compromise, agree to inform our end customer of these limitations in writing in lieu of including these limitations in the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances our licensors will ask that Zebracorp assumes liability for any breach of the sublicense terms and restrictions by its customers.
content.plain_text: Licensors sometimes request Zebracorp to assume liability for customer breaches of sublicense terms.
content.expert_insight: Describes another common licensor request.
content.text: In some instances our licensors will ask that Zebracorp assumes liability for any breach of the sublicense terms and restrictions by its customers.

content.verbatim_text: This is not something that we can accept.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp cannot accept liability for customer breaches of sublicense terms.
content.expert_insight: Clear statement of an unacceptable term.
content.justification: Customers are independent third parties, and Zebracorp cannot control their actions or guarantee their behavior.
content.implication_company: Accepting this would expose Zebracorp to uncontrollable and potentially massive liabilities.
content.text: This is not something that we can accept.

content.verbatim_text: The customers are independent third parties and Zebracorp cannot control the actions of its customers or give any guarantees of behalf of such parties.
content.plain_text: Customers are independent third parties, and Zebracorp cannot control their actions or provide guarantees on their behalf.
content.expert_insight: Explains the fundamental reason for rejecting such liability.
content.text: The customers are independent third parties and Zebracorp cannot control the actions of its customers or give any guarantees of behalf of such parties.

content.verbatim_text: At best, we can contractually bind the customers to certain license terms and restrictions and report any violations to our licensor.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can, at most, contractually bind customers to license terms and report violations to the licensor.
content.expert_insight: Defines the practical limits of Zebracorp's ability to manage customer compliance.
content.text: At best, we can contractually bind the customers to certain license terms and restrictions and report any violations to our licensor.

content.verbatim_text: In the event of such requests, we can propose the below alternative wording instead: “If [Zebracorp] becomes aware of any material breach of any of the license terms and restrictions by its [Customer], [Zebracorp] shall promptly notify the [Licensor] thereof. In the event of the occurrence of any such material breach, the [Parties] shall consult in good faith on the next steps with respect to such breach and enforcement of such license restrictions”.
content.plain_text: As an alternative to assuming liability, Zebracorp can propose wording where it promptly notifies the licensor of material breaches by customers, and then parties consult in good faith on next steps.
content.expert_insight: Provides a specific, acceptable compromise clause for managing customer breaches.
content.text: In the event of such requests, we can propose the below alternative wording instead: “If [Zebracorp] becomes aware of any material breach of any of the license terms and restrictions by its [Customer], [Zebracorp] shall promptly notify the [Licensor] thereof. In the event of the occurrence of any such material breach, the [Parties] shall consult in good faith on the next steps with respect to such breach and enforcement of such license restrictions”.

content.verbatim_text: Note that all of the license rights should extend to the Zebracorp Group as a whole.
content.plain_text: All license rights must extend to the entire Zebracorp Group.
content.expert_insight: Essential for the operational flexibility and legal coverage of a multinational corporation.
content.implication_company: Ensures all Zebracorp entities can legally use the licensed products, preventing operational bottlenecks and compliance issues.
content.text: Note that all of the license rights should extend to the Zebracorp Group as a whole.

content.verbatim_text: The Zebracorp entity that signs the contract is not necessarily the same as the ordering Zebracorp entity.
content.plain_text: The Zebracorp entity signing a contract may differ from the ordering entity.
content.expert_insight: Explains a common corporate structure issue that necessitates broad license coverage.
content.text: The Zebracorp entity that signs the contract is not necessarily the same as the ordering Zebracorp entity.

content.verbatim_text: Moreover, the actual distribution and sublicensing or usage of the licensed products may be by a local Zebracorp entity as opposed to the entity that entered into the contract with the licensor.
content.plain_text: Local Zebracorp entities, not just the contracting entity, may handle distribution, sublicensing, or usage.
content.expert_insight: Further justification for extending rights to the entire group.
content.text: Moreover, the actual distribution and sublicensing or usage of the licensed products may be by a local Zebracorp entity as opposed to the entity that entered into the contract with the licensor.

content.verbatim_text: In each case the affiliates of Zebracorp should obtain the same rights as the signing Zebracorp entity.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp affiliates must receive the same license rights as the signing entity.
content.expert_insight: Reinforces the need for comprehensive coverage across the group.
content.implication_company: Ensures legal compliance and operational continuity for all relevant Zebracorp entities.
content.text: In each case the affiliates of Zebracorp should obtain the same rights as the signing Zebracorp entity.

content.verbatim_text: The license grants should also allow our dedicated contractors to make use of the license rights when in e.g. making permitted adaptations to the licensed product etc. or when distributing the licensed products.
content.plain_text: License grants should permit dedicated contractors to use license rights for permitted adaptations or distribution.
content.expert_insight: Important for Zebracorp's operational flexibility, especially when relying on third-party contractors.
content.implication_company: Enables Zebracorp to leverage external expertise for development and distribution.
content.text: The license grants should also allow our dedicated contractors to make use of the license rights when in e.g. making permitted adaptations to the licensed product etc. or when distributing the licensed products.

content.verbatim_text: The above is reflected in the provisions found in our inlicensing agreement templates that contain the following language: “Any license granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall include Affiliates and contractor(s) of [Licensee]”.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's in-licensing templates include clauses like: "Any license granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall include Affiliates and contractor(s) of [Licensee]".
content.expert_insight: Shows how this requirement is typically addressed in Zebracorp's contracts.
content.text: The above is reflected in the provisions found in our inlicensing agreement templates that contain the following language: “Any license granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall include Affiliates and contractor(s) of [Licensee]”.

content.verbatim_text: Where needed, we can remove some of the ambiguity surrounding the extent of the use by our contractors and revise this to read in e.g. as follows: “Any licenses granted to the [Licensee] shall also include the Affiliates of the [Licensee]. Any licenses granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall also extend to the subcontractors of [Licensee], but solely to the extent required for the purpose of enabling such subcontractors to perform work or provide services for [Licensee] (and its Affiliates) in support of this [Agreement], and not for the benefit of any third parties or for such subcontractor’s own benefit, and only while such subcontractors are providing such services to [Licensee] (and its Affiliates). For clarity, [Licensee] may not grant to its Affiliates and subcontractors any greater rights than [Licensee] has obtained from [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: To clarify contractor use, the clause can be revised to state that licenses extend to affiliates and subcontractors, but only for work/services for the licensee (and affiliates) in support of the agreement, not for third-party or subcontractor's own benefit, and only while providing such services. Also, the licensee cannot grant greater rights than obtained from the licensor.
content.expert_insight: Provides detailed language to precisely define the scope of contractor use, limiting it to Zebracorp's benefit and preventing unauthorized broader use. This is a crucial clarification to protect the licensor's IP while allowing Zebracorp operational flexibility.
content.text: Where needed, we can remove some of the ambiguity surrounding the extent of the use by our contractors and revise this to read in e.g. as follows: “Any licenses granted to the [Licensee] shall also include the Affiliates of the [Licensee]. Any licenses granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall also extend to the subcontractors of [Licensee], but solely to the extent required for the purpose of enabling such subcontractors to perform work or provide services for [Licensee] (and its Affiliates) in support of this [Agreement], and not for the benefit of any third parties or for such subcontractor’s own benefit, and only while such subcontractors are providing such services to [Licensee] (and its Affiliates). For clarity, [Licensee] may not grant to its Affiliates and subcontractors any greater rights than [Licensee] has obtained from [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: The license grant should give Zebracorp the necessary rights to each conceivable use of the licensed software/technology.
content.plain_text: The license grant must provide Zebracorp with all necessary rights for every conceivable use of the licensed software/technology.
content.expert_insight: This is Zebracorp's overarching strategic goal for license grants.
content.implication_company: Ensures Zebracorp's business operations and future innovations are not constrained by insufficient licensing.
content.text: The license grant should give Zebracorp the necessary rights to each conceivable use of the licensed software/technology.

content.verbatim_text: Note that this is not necessarily reflected in the boilerplate license grants found in Zebracorp procurement contract templates, but those should be modified to reflect the actual needs for each case in hand.
content.plain_text: Boilerplate license grants in Zebracorp templates may not cover all needs and should be customized for each specific case.
content.expert_insight: Emphasizes the importance of tailoring contracts beyond standard templates.
content.implication_company: Prevents Zebracorp from being under-licensed due to generic contract language.
content.text: Note that this is not necessarily reflected in the boilerplate license grants found in Zebracorp procurement contract templates, but those should be modified to reflect the actual needs for each case in hand.

content.verbatim_text: In direct procurement contracts, it is important to make sure that the licenses also give Zebracorp the right to distribute/sublicense to its end customers and that such end customers obtain perpetual licenses (save where the license is specifically tied to a certain time frame).
content.plain_text: In direct procurement, ensure licenses grant Zebracorp the right to distribute/sublicense to end customers, and that end customers receive perpetual licenses (unless time-limited).
content.expert_insight: Reiteration of key requirements for Zebracorp's core business model.
content.implication_company: Fundamental for Zebracorp's ability to operate as a reseller and provide stable products to its customers.
content.text: In direct procurement contracts, it is important to make sure that the licenses also give Zebracorp the right to distribute/sublicense to its end customers and that such end customers obtain perpetual licenses (save where the license is specifically tied to a certain time frame).

content.verbatim_text: The license grant clause essentially defines the scope of the license i.e. the rights which the licensor grants to the licensee to its software/technology and has commonly several components to it which effectively limit the rights granted.
content.plain_text: A license grant clause defines the scope of rights a licensor grants to a licensee for software/technology, often including components that limit these rights.
content.expert_insight: Understanding the precise scope of the license grant is fundamental to any licensing agreement, as it dictates what the licensee can and cannot do with the intellectual property. Pay close attention to any limiting components.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The license grant clause essentially defines the scope of the license i.e. the rights which the licensor grants to the licensee to its software/technology and has commonly several components to it which effectively limit the rights granted.

content.verbatim_text: Generally speaking it is in the interests of the licensor/supplier to keep the scope of the license as narrow as possible whereas it is in Zebracorp interest as the licensee to obtain as broad license rights as possible.
content.plain_text: Licensors/suppliers aim for narrow license scopes, while Zebracorp, as a licensee, should seek the broadest possible license rights.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a fundamental tension in license negotiations. Zebracorp's legal team must actively push for expansive rights, anticipating potential future uses, while licensors will naturally try to limit them to protect their IP and maximize revenue.
content.justification: This is a general strategic principle for negotiations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should proactively negotiate for broader license rights to ensure maximum flexibility and utility of the licensed software/technology.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will aim to draft license grants narrowly to retain control over their intellectual property and potentially create opportunities for additional revenue streams through expanded licenses.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Generally speaking it is in the interests of the licensor/supplier to keep the scope of the license as narrow as possible whereas it is in Zebracorp interest as the licensee to obtain as broad license rights as possible.

content.verbatim_text: The license can be either “exclusive” or “non-exclusive”. Most licenses that Zebracorp obtains from its suppliers and licensors are non-exclusive (meaning that the licensor may license the same IPR to its other customers as well and not only Zebracorp).
content.plain_text: Licenses can be 'exclusive' (only one licensee) or 'non-exclusive' (licensor can license to others). Zebracorp typically obtains non-exclusive licenses.
content.expert_insight: The distinction between exclusive and non-exclusive is critical. A non-exclusive license allows the licensor to continue licensing the IP to other parties, which is common for standard software products. Exclusive licenses are rare and carry significant implications.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The license can be either “exclusive” or “non-exclusive”. Most licenses that Zebracorp obtains from its suppliers and licensors are non-exclusive (meaning that the licensor may license the same IPR to its other customers as well and not only Zebracorp).

content.verbatim_text: It is recommended to discuss with Legal & Compliance whenever agreeing to an exclusive license as such exclusivity may have unforeseen legal implications that may need to be taken into account.
content.plain_text: Always consult Legal & Compliance before agreeing to an exclusive license due to potential unforeseen legal implications.
content.expert_insight: Exclusive licenses can trigger antitrust concerns, market dominance issues, and significantly impact a licensor's ability to monetize their IP. Legal & Compliance review is essential to mitigate these risks and understand the full scope of obligations and rights.
content.conditions: When agreeing to an exclusive license.
content.justification: Exclusive licenses may have unforeseen legal implications.
content.implication_company: Failure to consult Legal & Compliance could lead to significant legal risks, compliance issues, and potential financial penalties for Zebracorp.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers granting exclusive licenses should also be aware of the legal implications and ensure their agreements are compliant with relevant regulations.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is recommended to discuss with Legal & Compliance whenever agreeing to an exclusive license as such exclusivity may have unforeseen legal implications that may need to be taken into account.

content.verbatim_text: Most licenses are non-transferable meaning that they cannot be transferred by the licensee to another third party. Note that transferability of the license is not the same as the right to sublicense. By stating that the license is non-transferable, the licensee is effectively prevented from transferring the license horizontally to another entity or person. This restriction does not in itself contradict with the right to sublicense i.e. the right to “transfer” the license vertically to customers.
content.plain_text: Most licenses are non-transferable, meaning the licensee cannot transfer them to another third party. This differs from sublicensing, which allows 'vertical' transfer to customers, whereas non-transferability prevents 'horizontal' transfer to other entities.
content.expert_insight: The distinction between transferability and sublicensing is crucial. Non-transferable prevents assignment of the license itself, while sublicensing grants rights to third-party end-users. Zebracorp must ensure its sublicensing rights are clearly defined, especially for its business model.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Most licenses are non-transferable meaning that they cannot be transferred by the licensee to another third party. Note that transferability of the license is not the same as the right to sublicense. By stating that the license is non-transferable, the licensee is effectively prevented from transferring the license horizontally to another entity or person. This restriction does not in itself contradict with the right to sublicense i.e. the right to “transfer” the license vertically to customers.

content.verbatim_text: The license can also be either “worldwide” or restricted to certain territory or region only.
content.plain_text: Licenses can be either 'worldwide' or limited to specific territories or regions.
content.expert_insight: For a global company like Zebracorp, a worldwide license is often a default requirement to avoid complex regional licensing issues and ensure consistent product availability across markets.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The license can also be either “worldwide” or restricted to certain territory or region only.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp should seek to obtain worldwide licenses in its global in-licensing agreements. Any territorial restrictions should be carefully considered.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must aim for worldwide licenses in global in-licensing agreements and thoroughly evaluate any territorial restrictions.
content.expert_insight: Given Zebracorp's global operations, securing worldwide licenses is paramount to avoid fragmented rights and ensure seamless operation across all markets. Any proposed territorial restrictions must be justified by a clear business need and assessed for impact on global strategy.
content.conditions: In global in-licensing agreements.
content.justification: To support global operations and avoid fragmented rights.
content.implication_company: Failure to obtain worldwide licenses could restrict Zebracorp's ability to operate globally or require costly renegotiations for additional territories.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may prefer territorial restrictions to manage market segmentation or pricing, but Zebracorp's strong preference for worldwide licenses will be a key negotiation point.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Zebracorp should seek to obtain worldwide licenses in its global in-licensing agreements. Any territorial restrictions should be carefully considered.

content.verbatim_text: Typically the license grant will also say that the license is “perpetual” and “irrevocable”. In case we have not purchased a permanent license by paying a one-time non-recurring license fee, we may not require the license from the licensor to us to be either perpetual or irrevocable, but we can agree that the license is limited to the term of our mutual license agreement. Moreover, the license fee structure in itself may be such that the license fees entitle to time-based usage only which effectively renders the license limited in time.
content.plain_text: License grants are typically 'perpetual' and 'irrevocable'. However, if a permanent license wasn't purchased with a one-time fee, the license can be limited to the agreement's term, especially if fees are time-based.
content.expert_insight: The duration and revocability of a license are directly tied to the payment model. If Zebracorp is paying recurring fees, a perpetual and irrevocable license might not be necessary or appropriate for its own use, but it must consider the implications for its end-customers.
content.justification: Explains typical license terms and how they relate to payment structures.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to align the desired license duration (perpetual/irrevocable vs. term-limited) with its payment structure and business needs, especially for internal use.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will tie license duration and revocability to the pricing model, offering perpetual licenses for one-time fees and term-limited licenses for subscription-based models.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Typically the license grant will also say that the license is “perpetual” and “irrevocable”. In case we have not purchased a permanent license by paying a one-time non-recurring license fee, we may not require the license from the licensor to us to be either perpetual or irrevocable, but we can agree that the license is limited to the term of our mutual license agreement. Moreover, the license fee structure in itself may be such that the license fees entitle to time-based usage only which effectively renders the license limited in time.

content.verbatim_text: Note, however, that whenever we are distributing and sublicensing (see more on sublicensing in this chapter below) to our end customers we will require that the sublicenses that we have granted to our end customer during the term of the agreement is indeed perpetual and irrevocable (unless we have expressly agreed on a timebased license).
content.plain_text: When Zebracorp distributes and sublicenses to end customers, it must ensure those sublicenses are perpetual and irrevocable, unless a time-based license was explicitly agreed upon.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical requirement for Zebracorp's business model. End customers expect stable access to software, and Zebracorp must ensure its upstream licenses support its downstream commitments. Any deviation (e.g., time-based sublicenses) must be a deliberate business decision.
content.conditions: When distributing and sublicensing to end customers.
content.justification: To ensure stability and continuity for end customers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must secure perpetual and irrevocable rights from its licensors for any software it intends to sublicense to end customers on a perpetual basis, to avoid future liabilities or service disruptions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be aware that Zebracorp will require perpetual and irrevocable sublicensing rights for its end customers, which may influence the pricing and terms of the primary license.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Note, however, that whenever we are distributing and sublicensing (see more on sublicensing in this chapter below) to our end customers we will require that the sublicenses that we have granted to our end customer during the term of the agreement is indeed perpetual and irrevocable (unless we have expressly agreed on a timebased license).

content.verbatim_text: In the majority of license agreements it may not be necessary to spell out that the license is ‘fully paid-up’ even if the majority of Zebracorp procurement contract templates contain such attribute in the license grant. This attribute can often be deleted as the fact that the license fee/royalty is or is not paid off can be dealt with in the payments section of the agreement.
content.plain_text: It's often unnecessary to explicitly state 'fully paid-up' in license agreements, even if Zebracorp templates include it. This can be removed, as payment status belongs in the payments section.
content.expert_insight: Streamlining contract language by removing redundant clauses can improve clarity and reduce negotiation friction. Payment status is a commercial term best handled in the dedicated payment section, not the license grant's scope.
content.justification: The payment status can be dealt with in the payments section.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can simplify its license grant clauses and reduce unnecessary negotiation points by removing the 'fully paid-up' attribute.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might appreciate the simplification, but will ensure payment terms are clearly defined elsewhere.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In the majority of license agreements it may not be necessary to spell out that the license is ‘fully paid-up’ even if the majority of Zebracorp procurement contract templates contain such attribute in the license grant. This attribute can often be deleted as the fact that the license fee/royalty is or is not paid off can be dealt with in the payments section of the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: The aforesaid does, however, not apply to trial licenses where it is in fact recommended to expressly state that such licenses are free-of-charge.
content.plain_text: For trial licenses, it is recommended to explicitly state that they are free-of-charge.
content.expert_insight: Clarity is paramount for trial licenses to avoid any ambiguity regarding payment obligations, especially if the trial could lead to a paid subscription. Explicitly stating 'free-of-charge' prevents disputes.
content.conditions: For trial licenses.
content.justification: To avoid ambiguity regarding payment obligations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure all trial license agreements clearly state they are free-of-charge to prevent any claims for payment.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers offering trial licenses benefit from this clarity to manage expectations and avoid disputes over payment.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The aforesaid does, however, not apply to trial licenses where it is in fact recommended to expressly state that such licenses are free-of-charge.

content.verbatim_text: In those cases where the agreement is used for the procurement of both hardware and stand alone software applications, it is often worthwhile making a distinction between the licenses for the hardware (incl. any firmware or embedded software) and any stand alone software applications.
content.plain_text: When procuring both hardware and standalone software, it is advisable to distinguish between their respective licenses, including firmware or embedded software.
content.expert_insight: Hardware and software licenses often have different terms, scope, and implications. Separating them clarifies rights and obligations for each component, preventing confusion and ensuring appropriate terms are applied.
content.justification: To ensure clarity and appropriate terms for each component.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its contracts clearly delineate licenses for hardware and software components to avoid ambiguities in rights and responsibilities.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to provide distinct license terms for hardware and software, especially for complex integrated solutions.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In those cases where the agreement is used for the procurement of both hardware and stand alone software applications, it is often worthwhile making a distinction between the licenses for the hardware (incl. any firmware or embedded software) and any stand alone software applications.

content.verbatim_text: Hardware in itself may often not merit a specific license grant. When used hardware licenses are often fairly broad and non-contentious, which is why this section will focus on software licenses alone. The licenses for firmware that cannot be accessed by the end user can often follow the broad licenses that accompany the hardware or device where the firmware is installed.
content.plain_text: Hardware often doesn't require a specific license grant, and hardware licenses are typically broad and non-contentious. Firmware inaccessible to end-users can follow the hardware's broad license.
content.expert_insight: This provides context on the relative simplicity of hardware and embedded firmware licensing compared to standalone software, justifying the focus on software license complexities.
content.justification: Provides background context on hardware and firmware licensing.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can expect less complexity in hardware and embedded firmware licensing, allowing more focus on standalone software terms.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers typically offer broad, less contentious licenses for hardware and embedded firmware, simplifying negotiations in these areas.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Hardware in itself may often not merit a specific license grant. When used hardware licenses are often fairly broad and non-contentious, which is why this section will focus on software licenses alone. The licenses for firmware that cannot be accessed by the end user can often follow the broad licenses that accompany the hardware or device where the firmware is installed.

content.verbatim_text: License Restrictions. Many license agreements also contain specific restrictions that seek to protect the licensor’s intellectual property rights in the licensed software/technology.
content.plain_text: License agreements commonly include specific restrictions to protect the licensor's intellectual property rights in the licensed software/technology.
content.expert_insight: Restrictions are a standard part of IP licensing, designed to prevent unauthorized use, modification, or distribution that could devalue the licensor's assets. Zebracorp must carefully review these to ensure they don't impede legitimate business operations.
content.justification: General information about license restrictions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully review all license restrictions to ensure they do not unduly hinder its intended use of the software/technology.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers rely on these restrictions to protect their IP and control its usage.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: License Restrictions. Many license agreements also contain specific restrictions that seek to protect the licensor’s intellectual property rights in the licensed software/technology.

content.verbatim_text: “Except as otherwise agreed in this Agreement, Licensee is not entitled and shall not authorize or permit any third party to: (i) copy, alter or in any way modify the [Licensed Products] or create derivative works thereof without the prior written consent of the [Licensor]; (ii) decompile, disassemble, reverse compile, reverse assemble, reverse translate or otherwise reverse engineer the [Licensed Products] or in any other manner reduce the [Licensed Products] to source code or human perceivable form except to the extent the foregoing restrictions are not permissible under mandatory law; or (iii) use the [Licensed Products] as a service bureau, rental, timeshare or in a hosted environment. ”
content.plain_text: An example of common license restrictions includes prohibitions against copying, altering, modifying, creating derivative works, reverse engineering, or using the products as a service bureau, rental, timeshare, or in a hosted environment, unless otherwise agreed or permitted by law.
content.expert_insight: This example provides a clear template for typical restrictions. Zebracorp must identify which of these restrictions conflict with its business model (e.g., hosting, creating adaptations) and negotiate explicit exceptions.
content.justification: Provides a direct example of typical license restrictions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to identify which of these common restrictions conflict with its operational needs (e.g., hosting, adaptations) and negotiate explicit carve-outs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers typically include these clauses to protect their IP, and will expect licensees to adhere to them unless specific exceptions are negotiated.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: “Except as otherwise agreed in this Agreement, Licensee is not entitled and shall not authorize or permit any third party to: (i) copy, alter or in any way modify the [Licensed Products] or create derivative works thereof without the prior written consent of the [Licensor]; (ii) decompile, disassemble, reverse compile, reverse assemble, reverse translate or otherwise reverse engineer the [Licensed Products] or in any other manner reduce the [Licensed Products] to source code or human perceivable form except to the extent the foregoing restrictions are not permissible under mandatory law; or (iii) use the [Licensed Products] as a service bureau, rental, timeshare or in a hosted environment. ”

content.verbatim_text: However, it is recommended to state specifically that the above restrictions do not apply in cases where the parties have expressly agreed otherwise in the agreement (see underlined section in the above example). This is necessary because we may have in e.g. agreed a right to make copies of the licensed software/technology. In many cases we also require a right to use the licensed products in a hosted environment or a right to make the licensed products available to our customers as a service.
content.plain_text: It is recommended to explicitly state that standard restrictions do not apply if parties have agreed otherwise. This is crucial because Zebracorp may need rights like making copies, using products in a hosted environment, or offering them as a service.
content.expert_insight: Adding an 'except as otherwise agreed' clause provides flexibility. Zebracorp must ensure that any specific rights it negotiates (e.g., for hosting or adaptations) explicitly override standard restrictions to avoid conflict.
content.conditions: When standard license restrictions are present.
content.justification: Zebracorp may require rights (e.g., copying, hosting, service provision) that contradict standard restrictions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its negotiated rights are not inadvertently nullified by standard restriction clauses, requiring careful drafting and explicit exceptions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to negotiate specific carve-outs to their standard restrictions to accommodate Zebracorp's business model, particularly for hosting and service provision.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: However, it is recommended to state specifically that the above restrictions do not apply in cases where the parties have expressly agreed otherwise in the agreement (see underlined section in the above example). This is necessary because we may have in e.g. agreed a right to make copies of the licensed software/technology. In many cases we also require a right to use the licensed products in a hosted environment or a right to make the licensed products available to our customers as a service.

content.verbatim_text: It may be worthwhile clarifying that our end customer (i.e. the industrial customer) may use the licensed software/technology to offer services to its subscribers through a hosted platform. This can be accomplished by adding in e.g. the following note: “The end-customer cannot use the [Licensed Products] for rental, timesharing, hosting or service bureau purposes, but such end-customer shall be entitled to use the [Licensed Products] to provide cloud-based or hosting services to its subscribers.”
content.plain_text: Clarify that end customers can use licensed software/technology to offer services via a hosted platform, even if direct hosting by the end-customer is restricted. An example note: 'The end-customer cannot use the [Licensed Products] for rental, timesharing, hosting or service bureau purposes, but such end-customer shall be entitled to use the [Licensed Products] to provide cloud-based or hosting services to its subscribers.'
content.expert_insight: This specific clarification is vital for Zebracorp's business model, particularly if its end customers are service providers. It distinguishes between the end-customer *using* the product to offer services (acceptable) and *being* a service bureau for the product itself (often restricted).
content.justification: To enable end customers to use the licensed products for providing cloud-based or hosting services to their subscribers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its sublicense agreements with end customers clearly grant them the right to use the software for providing services, differentiating from general hosting prohibitions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers need to understand Zebracorp's business model and be willing to include such clarifications to enable Zebracorp's end customers to offer services.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It may be worthwhile clarifying that our end customer (i.e. the industrial customer) may use the licensed software/technology to offer services to its subscribers through a hosted platform. This can be accomplished by adding in e.g. the following note: “The end-customer cannot use the [Licensed Products] for rental, timesharing, hosting or service bureau purposes, but such end-customer shall be entitled to use the [Licensed Products] to provide cloud-based or hosting services to its subscribers.”

content.verbatim_text: It may also be recommended to specifically state that the restrictions should not prevent Zebracorp managed services business. This can be accomplished by making the following or similar clarification: “For clarity, none of the foregoing shall restrict [Zebracorp] from using the [Licensed Products] on behalf of its[end-customers to provide managed services of such end-customer’s operations.”
content.plain_text: It is recommended to explicitly state that license restrictions do not hinder Zebracorp's managed services business, for example, by adding a clause clarifying that Zebracorp can use the products on behalf of end-customers for managed services.
content.expert_insight: This is a non-negotiable point for Zebracorp if managed services are part of its offering. Without this explicit carve-out, standard 'service bureau' or 'hosted environment' restrictions could inadvertently prevent Zebracorp from operating its core business.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp operates a managed services business.
content.justification: To ensure license restrictions do not prevent Zebracorp from providing managed services.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must secure this clarification to protect its managed services business model and avoid legal challenges.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must acknowledge and accommodate Zebracorp's managed services model by explicitly allowing such use within the license terms.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It may also be recommended to specifically state that the restrictions should not prevent Zebracorp managed services business. This can be accomplished by making the following or similar clarification: “For clarity, none of the foregoing shall restrict [Zebracorp] from using the [Licensed Products] on behalf of its[end-customers to provide managed services of such end-customer’s operations.”

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the nature of the licensed software/technology, there are also number of additional requirements and elements that the licensor may require in connection with granting us the licenses to its software/technology. The licensor may in e.g. specify maximum number of concurrent users, or require that their software is distributed and sublicensed only in connection with certain named Zebracorp products, or require that the software can only be used in certain defined platforms.
content.plain_text: Licensors may impose additional requirements based on the software/technology, such as maximum concurrent users, distribution only with specific Zebracorp products, or usage on defined platforms.
content.expert_insight: These are common commercial restrictions tied to pricing and product strategy. Zebracorp needs to anticipate these and ensure they align with its business plan and technical infrastructure.
content.justification: Provides context on additional licensor requirements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must evaluate if these additional requirements align with its business model, product strategy, and technical capabilities.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers use these restrictions to control product usage, pricing, and market positioning.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Depending on the nature of the licensed software/technology, there are also number of additional requirements and elements that the licensor may require in connection with granting us the licenses to its software/technology. The licensor may in e.g. specify maximum number of concurrent users, or require that their software is distributed and sublicensed only in connection with certain named Zebracorp products, or require that the software can only be used in certain defined platforms.

content.verbatim_text: In most cases, such additional restrictions should be addressed in the product/pricing appendix instead of the license grant section as these restrictions can change over time and they are often tied to pricing.
content.plain_text: Additional restrictions, especially those tied to pricing or prone to change, should typically be placed in the product/pricing appendix rather than the main license grant section.
content.expert_insight: Keeping dynamic commercial terms out of the core agreement text makes amendments easier and avoids frequent renegotiations of the main license. This also helps maintain a cleaner, more stable license grant.
content.justification: These restrictions can change over time and are often tied to pricing.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should advocate for placing such dynamic terms in appendices for easier management and updates.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might find this approach beneficial for managing product variations and pricing updates without altering the core license agreement.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In most cases, such additional restrictions should be addressed in the product/pricing appendix instead of the license grant section as these restrictions can change over time and they are often tied to pricing.

content.verbatim_text: In any event, the feasibility of such additional restrictions should in each case be confirmed with the respective CT/product line.
content.plain_text: The feasibility of any additional license restrictions must always be confirmed with the relevant Customer Team (CT) or product line.
content.expert_insight: This ensures that legal agreements align with operational realities and product capabilities. Technical and business teams are best positioned to assess the practical impact of proposed restrictions.
content.conditions: When additional license restrictions are proposed.
content.justification: To ensure the restrictions are practical and align with business and technical capabilities.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must establish an internal process to involve CT/product lines in reviewing license restrictions to prevent signing agreements that are technically or operationally unfeasible.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared for Zebracorp to internally vet proposed restrictions for feasibility.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In any event, the feasibility of such additional restrictions should in each case be confirmed with the respective CT/product line.

content.verbatim_text: Most license grant clauses require the licensee to explicitly list those rights which the licensee requires. In fact most Zebracorp in-licensing contract templates will say that: “There are no implied licenses granted under this [Agreement], and all rights, save for those expressly granted to [Zebracorp] hereunder, shall remain with the [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: Most license grants require explicit listing of licensee rights. Zebracorp templates often state that no implied licenses are granted, and all ungranted rights remain with the licensor.
content.expert_insight: This 'no implied licenses' clause is standard to protect licensors. Zebracorp must be diligent in explicitly enumerating all necessary rights to avoid future disputes over unstated permissions.
content.justification: Provides context on the explicit nature of license grants and common template language.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be meticulous in explicitly detailing all required rights in the license grant, as implied rights are generally disclaimed.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from this clarity, ensuring that any rights not explicitly granted are retained.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Most license grant clauses require the licensee to explicitly list those rights which the licensee requires. In fact most Zebracorp in-licensing contract templates will say that: “There are no implied licenses granted under this [Agreement], and all rights, save for those expressly granted to [Zebracorp] hereunder, shall remain with the [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: A commonly used license grant in software license agreements will provide the following rights and licenses: right to use, make copies, to distribute and to sublicense.
content.plain_text: Common software license grants include rights to use, make copies, distribute, and sublicense.
content.expert_insight: These four rights form the foundation of many software licenses. Zebracorp needs to ensure it secures all of these, particularly distribute and sublicense, for its business model.
content.justification: Lists commonly granted rights in software licenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure these fundamental rights are included in its license agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers typically offer these core rights, with variations and restrictions.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: A commonly used license grant in software license agreements will provide the following rights and licenses: right to use, make copies, to distribute and to sublicense.

content.verbatim_text: As for the right to use, it is often necessary to define in more detail what that right entails. In direct procurement, Zebracorp generally does not require the right to use the software by itself but the focus is on the right to distribute and sublicense to our end customers. We may require the right to use the licensed software/technology in e.g. for making adaptations by adding Zebracorp look and feel to the licensed software or a right to use certain software to provide technical support.
content.plain_text: The 'right to use' often needs detailed definition. In direct procurement, Zebracorp's focus is usually on distribution and sublicensing, though it might need use rights for adaptations (e.g., adding Zebracorp branding) or technical support.
content.expert_insight: While 'use' seems simple, its scope can be highly contentious. Zebracorp must specify its particular use cases, especially for customization or support, to avoid ambiguity and potential infringement.
content.justification: Explains the nuances of the 'right to use' for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must clearly define its specific 'right to use' requirements, particularly for adaptations or support functions, to avoid limitations on its operations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to negotiate and define the scope of 'right to use' based on Zebracorp's specific needs.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: As for the right to use, it is often necessary to define in more detail what that right entails. In direct procurement, Zebracorp generally does not require the right to use the software by itself but the focus is on the right to distribute and sublicense to our end customers. We may require the right to use the licensed software/technology in e.g. for making adaptations by adding Zebracorp look and feel to the licensed software or a right to use certain software to provide technical support.

content.verbatim_text: In each case, we can define such use in the license grant so that the right to use is not too broad for the licensor to accept. As an example the license to adapt can, depending on our individual requirements, be narrowed down to read: “…a license to adapt the [Licensed Products] for the purposes of creating software application programming interfaces between the [Licensed Products] and the [ZEBRACORP Product]…”. Often the key for the supplier is that our right to adapt their product is not too broad.
content.plain_text: Define 'right to use' narrowly in the license grant to be acceptable to the licensor. For example, a license to adapt can be specified for creating APIs between licensed and Zebracorp products, addressing supplier concerns about overly broad adaptation rights.
content.expert_insight: Precision in defining rights, even if seemingly restrictive, can facilitate agreement. By narrowing the scope of 'adapt' to specific, necessary functions (like API creation), Zebracorp can secure critical rights without alarming the licensor about uncontrolled modifications.
content.justification: To ensure the right to use is acceptable to the licensor while meeting Zebracorp's needs.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be prepared to define its 'right to use' requirements with specific examples and narrow scope to increase licensor acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be more willing to grant specific 'right to use' clauses if they are narrowly defined and tied to clear business purposes.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In each case, we can define such use in the license grant so that the right to use is not too broad for the licensor to accept. As an example the license to adapt can, depending on our individual requirements, be narrowed down to read: “…a license to adapt the [Licensed Products] for the purposes of creating software application programming interfaces between the [Licensed Products] and the [ZEBRACORP Product]…”. Often the key for the supplier is that our right to adapt their product is not too broad.

content.verbatim_text: The right to make copies is less relevant in today’s market where the software is delivered electronically and downloadable or accessible directly from the vendor’s website. It is however, also possible that the software is provided through a master DVD/CD or that Zebracorp obtains a single copy on-premise which is then used to make further copies.
content.plain_text: The right to make copies is less relevant with electronic delivery but still important if software is provided via physical media or a single on-premise copy for further duplication.
content.expert_insight: While less critical for cloud-based or downloadable software, the right to copy remains important for on-premise deployments, disaster recovery, backup, and development environments. Zebracorp should assess its operational needs before waiving this right.
content.justification: Provides context on the relevance of the right to make copies.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to assess its deployment model (cloud vs. on-premise, physical media) to determine the necessity of the 'right to make copies'.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may try to limit the 'right to make copies' if their distribution model is primarily electronic, but should be prepared for specific requests for on-premise scenarios.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The right to make copies is less relevant in today’s market where the software is delivered electronically and downloadable or accessible directly from the vendor’s website. It is however, also possible that the software is provided through a master DVD/CD or that Zebracorp obtains a single copy on-premise which is then used to make further copies.

content.verbatim_text: The term right to reproduce which is commonly found in license grants is essentially the same as with the right to make copies and can be deleted if we do not require a right to make copies.
content.plain_text: The 'right to reproduce' is synonymous with the 'right to make copies' and can be removed from license grants if copying rights are not needed.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies redundant terminology. Removing 'right to reproduce' when 'right to make copies' is either present or unnecessary streamlines the contract.

content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The term right to reproduce which is commonly found in license grants is essentially the same as with the right to make copies and can be deleted if we do not require a right to make copies.

content.verbatim_text: The right to distribute is closely associated with the right to sublicense. The right to distribute is a key term in direct procurement and should always be included when Zebracorp is planning to further sell the software to its end customers.
content.plain_text: The right to distribute is crucial in direct procurement and must always be included when Zebracorp intends to resell software to end customers.
content.expert_insight: For Zebracorp's reseller model, the right to distribute is fundamental. Without it, Zebracorp cannot legally pass the software to its end customers, making it a deal-breaker clause.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp plans to sell software to end customers.
content.justification: It is a key term in direct procurement for reselling software.
content.implication_company: Failure to include the right to distribute would severely hinder Zebracorp's ability to resell software to its end customers, impacting its core business model.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be aware that Zebracorp will require the right to distribute for any software intended for resale.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The right to distribute is closely associated with the right to sublicense. The right to distribute is a key term in direct procurement and should always be included when Zebracorp is planning to further sell the software to its end customers.

content.verbatim_text: The right to distribute should include a right to use resellers and distributors or other sales channels in the sales interface. This is achieved by stating in the license grant that Zebracorp has the right to distribute “directly or indirectly”.
content.plain_text: The right to distribute should encompass the use of resellers, distributors, or other sales channels, explicitly stating Zebracorp's right to distribute 'directly or indirectly' in the license grant.
content.expert_insight: This ensures Zebracorp has maximum flexibility in its sales strategy. 'Directly or indirectly' is key language to cover all potential distribution models, including third-party channels.
content.conditions: When defining the right to distribute.
content.justification: To allow for the use of various sales channels, including resellers and distributors.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure this language is present to support its diverse sales and distribution network.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may object to indirect sales, requiring negotiation on this point.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The right to distribute should include a right to use resellers and distributors or other sales channels in the sales interface. This is achieved by stating in the license grant that Zebracorp has the right to distribute “directly or indirectly”.

content.verbatim_text: The vendors may take objection to such indirect sales and it is sometimes beneficial to specify that Zebracorp will not be using any direct competitors of the software vendor as its sales channel.
content.plain_text: Vendors may object to indirect sales; it can be beneficial to specify that Zebracorp will not use the vendor's direct competitors as sales channels.
content.expert_insight: This is a common compromise. Addressing a vendor's competitive concerns can unlock broader distribution rights. Zebracorp should be prepared to offer this assurance if it doesn't conflict with its own strategic partnerships.
content.justification: To alleviate vendor objections to indirect sales.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp may need to make strategic decisions about its sales channels to secure broader distribution rights, potentially limiting partnerships with direct competitors of its licensors.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will appreciate this concession as it protects their market position.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The vendors may take objection to such indirect sales and it is sometimes beneficial to specify that Zebracorp will not be using any direct competitors of the software vendor as its sales channel.

content.verbatim_text: Sales channels are commonly used in countries where Zebracorp does not have the necessary import licenses or in countries where Zebracorp does not have local presence.
content.plain_text: Sales channels are often utilized in countries where Zebracorp lacks import licenses or local presence.
content.expert_insight: This explains the operational necessity for indirect distribution, reinforcing why 'directly or indirectly' is a critical clause for Zebracorp's global reach.
content.justification: Explains the operational reasons for using sales channels.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's reliance on sales channels for market access in certain regions underscores the importance of securing broad distribution rights.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers gain insight into Zebracorp's operational needs for indirect distribution.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Sales channels are commonly used in countries where Zebracorp does not have the necessary import licenses or in countries where Zebracorp does not have local presence.

content.verbatim_text: In order to further alleviate the concerns of the vendors, we can also specify in the contract that such resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality undertakings that are no less restrictive that those agreed between the vendor and Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: To ease vendor concerns, contracts can specify that Zebracorp's resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality undertakings no less restrictive than those between the vendor and Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is a reasonable and common protective measure. Ensuring downstream confidentiality protects the licensor's IP while allowing Zebracorp to use its distribution network.
content.justification: To alleviate vendor concerns regarding the protection of their intellectual property.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its agreements with resellers/distributors include robust confidentiality clauses that meet or exceed the primary agreement's standards.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will likely find this a reasonable and acceptable safeguard for their IP.

content.text: In order to further alleviate the concerns of the vendors, we can also specify in the contract that such resellers/distributors will be bound by confidentiality undertakings that are no less restrictive that those agreed between the vendor and Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: However, having the supplier approve each distributor of Zebracorp, is more problematic and could be difficult or impossible to adhere to in practice.
content.plain_text: Requiring supplier approval for each of Zebracorp's distributors is problematic and impractical.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common point of friction. Supplier approval processes can severely bottleneck Zebracorp's sales operations and are generally unworkable for large distribution networks.
content.justification: Such a requirement is problematic and difficult to adhere to in practice.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must resist clauses requiring individual supplier approval for each distributor due to operational impracticality.

content.verbatim_text: Sub-licensing. As for the right to sublicense, the licensor may require additional protections on sublicenses, including requiring copies of any granted sublicenses, requiring the licensee to be responsible for compliance of sub-licensees and preventing the end users from sublicensing themselves.

content.expert_insight: These are common attempts by licensors to control the downstream chain. Zebracorp must carefully evaluate each request against its operational capabilities and risk appetite.
content.justification: Provides context on potential licensor requirements for sublicenses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to anticipate these requests and develop negotiation strategies to manage the associated obligations and risks.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will seek to protect their IP through these additional sublicense requirements.

content.text: Sub-licensing. As for the right to sublicense, the licensor may require additional protections on sublicenses, including requiring copies of any granted sublicenses, requiring the licensee to be responsible for compliance of sub-licensees and preventing the end users from sublicensing themselves.

content.verbatim_text: The latter requirement does not often present any problems since our end customers are in most cases the actual end users of the licensed software/technology.
content.plain_text: The requirement preventing end-users from sublicensing is usually not problematic, as Zebracorp's end customers are typically the actual end-users.
content.expert_insight: This indicates that for Zebracorp's typical customer base, the restriction on end-user sublicensing aligns with their actual usage patterns, simplifying this particular negotiation point.
content.justification: Explains why the restriction on end-user sublicensing is not problematic.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can generally agree to this restriction without impacting its core business.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect Zebracorp to agree to this restriction.
