content.text: The latter requirement does not often present any problems since our end customers are in most cases the actual end users of the licensed software/technology.

content.verbatim_text: However, we should not agree to provide the licensor copies of any agreements pursuant to which we have granted sublicenses to the licensed software/technology to our end customers. Our agreements with the end customers are confidential and we are not authorized to disclose those without the end customers’ prior written authorization. Zebracorp assurances that the sublicense will be granted to the end customers in accordance with the terms agreed between Zebracorp and the licensor should be sufficient.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must not agree to provide licensors with copies of sublicense agreements due to confidentiality obligations with end customers. Zebracorp's assurance that sublicenses comply with agreed terms should suffice.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical confidentiality and operational boundary. Disclosing customer contracts is a major breach of trust and often contractually prohibited. Zebracorp must firmly resist this, offering assurances instead.
content.conditions: When a licensor requests copies of sublicense agreements.
content.justification: End customer agreements are confidential and cannot be disclosed without prior written authorization.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must protect its end-customer confidentiality and avoid clauses that would force disclosure of sensitive business agreements.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers requesting such copies should be prepared for Zebracorp's refusal and accept assurances instead.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: However, we should not agree to provide the licensor copies of any agreements pursuant to which we have granted sublicenses to the licensed software/technology to our end customers. Our agreements with the end customers are confidential and we are not authorized to disclose those without the end customers’ prior written authorization. Zebracorp assurances that the sublicense will be granted to the end customers in accordance with the terms agreed between Zebracorp and the licensor should be sufficient.

content.verbatim_text: We should also not accept liability for any breach of the license terms by the end customers as such breaches are beyond our control.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not accept liability for end-customer breaches of license terms, as these are beyond its control.
content.expert_insight: Assuming liability for third-party actions is a significant risk. Zebracorp can only contractually bind its customers, not control them. This is a key risk mitigation position.
content.conditions: When negotiating sublicense terms.
content.justification: End customer breaches are beyond Zebracorp's control.
content.implication_company: Accepting such liability would expose Zebracorp to unacceptable risks and potential financial penalties for actions it cannot directly control.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may push for this, but Zebracorp will strongly resist, offering compromise solutions instead.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: We should also not accept liability for any breach of the license terms by the end customers as such breaches are beyond our control.

content.verbatim_text: As a compromise, we can propose in e.g. the following verbiage that basically puts an obligation on Zebracorp to monitor the usage by the end customer without accepting direct liability for the acts and omissions of the end customer: “[Zebracorp] will use commercially reasonable efforts to ensure that its sub-licensees comply with the respective license terms and will inform the [Licensor] promptly of any known violation, infringement or breach”.
content.plain_text: As a compromise, Zebracorp can propose language obligating it to use 'commercially reasonable efforts' to ensure sublicensee compliance and promptly inform the licensor of known violations, without accepting direct liability for end-customer acts.
content.expert_insight: This 'commercially reasonable efforts' clause is a standard and acceptable compromise. It demonstrates good faith and a commitment to compliance without accepting absolute liability for third-party behavior.
content.justification: Provides a compromise solution for managing end-customer compliance without accepting direct liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can mitigate risk by offering a 'commercially reasonable efforts' clause, which is a manageable operational obligation.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may accept this as a reasonable compromise, providing some assurance of compliance monitoring.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: As a compromise, we can propose in e.g. the following verbiage that basically puts an obligation on Zebracorp to monitor the usage by the end customer without accepting direct liability for the acts and omissions of the end customer: “[Zebracorp] will use commercially reasonable efforts to ensure that its sub-licensees comply with the respective license terms and will inform the [Licensor] promptly of any known violation, infringement or breach”.

content.verbatim_text: Further compromise can be made by adding: “Zebracorp will affirmatively enforce the sublicensing terms for the software licensed under the sublicense and further agrees that it will assist [Licensor] in the manner reasonably requested by [Licensor] in [Licensor]’s pursuit of an action against any third party for breach of the respective sublicense”.
content.plain_text: Another compromise is to agree that Zebracorp will affirmatively enforce sublicense terms and assist the licensor, as reasonably requested, in pursuing action against third-party breaches.
content.expert_insight: This further strengthens the 'reasonable efforts' approach by committing Zebracorp to active enforcement and cooperation. It's a strong compromise that offers significant value to the licensor without Zebracorp assuming direct liability.
content.justification: Provides a further compromise solution for managing end-customer compliance and enforcement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can offer this to demonstrate commitment to enforcement while still avoiding direct liability, but must ensure its internal processes support such enforcement and assistance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers would likely view this as a strong and acceptable compromise, providing them with recourse and assistance in case of breaches.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Further compromise can be made by adding: “Zebracorp will affirmatively enforce the sublicensing terms for the software licensed under the sublicense and further agrees that it will assist [Licensor] in the manner reasonably requested by [Licensor] in [Licensor]’s pursuit of an action against any third party for breach of the respective sublicense”.

content.verbatim_text: Barring certain exceptional cases, we are not in a position to agree to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to our end customers. This is largely due to the fact that our sales with our end customers are based on pre-existing frame sales contracts with already agreed and fixed terms and conditions.
content.plain_text: Except in rare cases, Zebracorp cannot agree to pass licensor's end-user license terms to its customers, as its sales are based on pre-existing frame sales contracts with fixed terms.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental operational constraint for Zebracorp. Its established customer contracts cannot be easily modified for each licensor. This position must be firmly held in negotiations.
content.conditions: When a licensor requires Zebracorp to pass on its end-user license terms.
content.justification: Zebracorp's sales are based on pre-existing, fixed frame sales contracts with end customers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must resist adopting licensor's EULTs directly into its customer contracts to maintain consistency and avoid operational disruption with its existing customer base.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must understand that Zebracorp's existing contract framework limits its ability to simply pass on supplier EULTs.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Barring certain exceptional cases, we are not in a position to agree to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to our end customers. This is largely due to the fact that our sales with our end customers are based on pre-existing frame sales contracts with already agreed and fixed terms and conditions.

content.verbatim_text: Any requirement to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to the end customer should be cleared with the respective Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.
content.plain_text: Any requirement to pass a licensor's end-user license terms to end customers must be cleared with the relevant Zebracorp Customer Team or Product Line.
content.expert_insight: This ensures that any deviation from Zebracorp's standard practice is a deliberate, informed business decision, with buy-in from the teams directly managing customer relationships.
content.conditions: When a licensor requires passing its end-user license terms to end customers.
content.justification: To ensure alignment with customer relationships and product strategy.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must have an internal process to escalate and approve such requirements, ensuring business and legal alignment.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect that such requests will undergo internal review within Zebracorp.

content.text: Any requirement to pass our licensor’s end user license terms to the end customer should be cleared with the respective Zebracorp Customer Team/Product Line.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp preferred position when it comes to sublicensing terms is to state that we will sublicense to the end customers on same terms that we accept for our own software.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred approach for sublicensing is to sublicense to end customers using the same terms it uses for its own software.
content.expert_insight: This approach promotes consistency and efficiency for Zebracorp. It leverages existing, vetted legal frameworks, reducing complexity and potential for error.
content.justification: To maintain consistency and efficiency with existing internal standards.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should strive to use its standard software terms for sublicensing to minimize legal and operational overhead.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may need to accept that Zebracorp will use its own standard terms for sublicenses.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Zebracorp preferred position when it comes to sublicensing terms is to state that we will sublicense to the end customers on same terms that we accept for our own software.

content.verbatim_text: Should this not be acceptable to the licensor, we can agree to say in e.g. that: “[Zebracorp] will sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its [End Customers] with license terms that are no less protective of the licensor’s rights than the license terms contained in this [Agreement].” Another equally acceptable compromise position may be found by adding in e.g. the following language: “[ZEBRACORP] may distribute and sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its customers provided that ZEBRACORP does not grant to any such customers any greater rights than [ZEBRACORP] has obtained from the [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp's preferred sublicensing terms are unacceptable to the licensor, compromises include stating that sublicense terms will be 'no less protective of the licensor’s rights' than the main agreement, or that Zebracorp will not grant 'any greater rights' to customers than it obtained from the licensor.
content.expert_insight: These are excellent compromise positions. They protect the licensor's IP without forcing Zebracorp to adopt the licensor's exact EULTs, providing flexibility while maintaining a 'pass-through' of core protections.
content.justification: Provides compromise solutions when Zebracorp's preferred sublicensing terms are not acceptable to the licensor.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use these compromise clauses to satisfy licensor concerns while maintaining flexibility in its customer contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should consider these as reasonable and protective alternatives to requiring direct adoption of their EULTs.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Should this not be acceptable to the licensor, we can agree to say in e.g. that: “[Zebracorp] will sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its [End Customers] with license terms that are no less protective of the licensor’s rights than the license terms contained in this [Agreement].” Another equally acceptable compromise position may be found by adding in e.g. the following language: “[ZEBRACORP] may distribute and sublicense the [Licensed Products] to its customers provided that ZEBRACORP does not grant to any such customers any greater rights than [ZEBRACORP] has obtained from the [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: In case the licensor required additional visibility on the license terms that we will be using with our end customers, we can agree to attach our standard Zebracorp End User License Terms to the agreement and state that “the sublicense will be granted on license terms that are substantially similar to those contained in the ZEBRACORP End User License Terms”. A copy of the Zebracorp End User License Terms is available to be obtained from any member of the Legal & Compliance team. When attaching the Zebracorp End User License Terms to our agreement with our licensor, we should only include the actual license terms and should remove any provisions that are not relevant to the actual license terms.
content.plain_text: If a licensor demands visibility into Zebracorp's end-customer license terms, Zebracorp can attach its standard EULTs to the agreement, stating sublicenses will be 'substantially similar'. When doing so, only include actual license terms, removing irrelevant provisions. Copies are available from Legal & Compliance.
content.expert_insight: This tactic offers transparency without full disclosure of specific customer contracts. It balances the licensor's need for assurance with Zebracorp's confidentiality and operational flexibility. Careful redaction of irrelevant terms is key.
content.justification: To provide licensor visibility on sublicense terms while protecting confidentiality and streamlining the attachment process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this method to satisfy licensor requests for visibility while managing its internal documentation and confidentiality concerns.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers gain transparency into the sublicense terms without requiring full access to confidential customer agreements.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In case the licensor required additional visibility on the license terms that we will be using with our end customers, we can agree to attach our standard Zebracorp End User License Terms to the agreement and state that “the sublicense will be granted on license terms that are substantially similar to those contained in the ZEBRACORP End User License Terms”. A copy of the Zebracorp End User License Terms is available to be obtained from any member of the Legal & Compliance team. When attaching the Zebracorp End User License Terms to our agreement with our licensor, we should only include the actual license terms and should remove any provisions that are not relevant to the actual license terms.

content.verbatim_text: Instead of enclosing our standard End User License Terms to the agreement, we can also expressly agree which minimum license terms need to be included in our sublicense agreement with the end customer. This approach would afford us greater flexibility in our contracting with our end customers (and as long as the list of such minimum terms remains customary and reasonable) and would be preferred over the inclusion of the Zebracorp End User License Terms.
content.plain_text: Instead of attaching full EULTs, Zebracorp can agree on a list of minimum license terms for sublicense agreements. This preferred approach offers greater flexibility in customer contracting, provided the minimum terms are customary and reasonable.
content.expert_insight: This is a highly flexible and preferred approach for Zebracorp. It allows for tailored customer contracts while ensuring core protections for the licensor. The 'customary and reasonable' caveat is important for successful negotiation.
content.justification: To afford greater flexibility in contracting with end customers while ensuring minimum protections for the licensor.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should prioritize this approach for its flexibility in managing customer-specific contracts, provided the minimum terms are acceptable.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may accept this if the minimum terms adequately protect their IP, offering a balance between protection and Zebracorp's operational flexibility.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Instead of enclosing our standard End User License Terms to the agreement, we can also expressly agree which minimum license terms need to be included in our sublicense agreement with the end customer. This approach would afford us greater flexibility in our contracting with our end customers (and as long as the list of such minimum terms remains customary and reasonable) and would be preferred over the inclusion of the Zebracorp End User License Terms.

content.verbatim_text: Below is an example of a clause where Zebracorp agrees to such minimum license terms: “[Zebracorp] agrees that any sublicensing of the [Licensed Products] to its [Customers] shall be pursuant to an agreement between [Zebracorp] and each Customer, which agreement will at the minimum contain substantially the following license terms: (A) the [Licensed Products] may not be used by anyone other than [Customer] (and its employees, agents or contractors) for its own internal business purposes, (B) the licenses to the [Licensed products] are limited, nonexclusive and non-transferable (C) the [Customer] does not have any ownership or intellectual property rights to the [Licensed Products] other than the right to use such [Licensed Products] in accordance with agreement between [Zebracorp] and the [Customer], (D) the [Customer] has no right to use the [Licensed Products] except as set forth in the product documentation, and (E) the [Customer] has no right to reverse engineering, decompiling, disassembling of the [Licensed Products], all of which is expressly prohibited.”
content.plain_text: An example clause for minimum sublicense terms includes: (A) use limited to customer's internal business, (B) licenses are limited, nonexclusive, non-transferable, (C) customer has no IP ownership beyond use rights, (D) use only as per documentation, and (E) no reverse engineering, decompiling, or disassembling.
content.expert_insight: This example provides a concrete set of minimum protective clauses. These are common and generally acceptable to licensors, as they safeguard core IP rights while allowing Zebracorp flexibility in other contractual aspects.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of minimum sublicense terms.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this as a template for negotiating minimum sublicense terms with licensors, ensuring fundamental protections are in place.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can review these terms to ensure they adequately protect their intellectual property when Zebracorp sublicenses.
content.source_insight: N/A

content.verbatim_text: It is not unusual for the software vendors to also require that we will also expressly limit the vendors liability in our end customer contract by in e.g. adding following provisions to our end customer contract: “[XYZ] Corporation disclaims all warranties, whether express or implied. [XYX] Corporation shall have no liability towards the [Customer] “.
content.plain_text: Software vendors often require Zebracorp to include clauses in its end-customer contracts that limit the vendor's liability, such as disclaiming all warranties and stating no liability towards the customer.
content.expert_insight: Licensors naturally seek to limit their downstream liability. Zebracorp must manage this tension with its own customer relationship and existing contract frameworks.
content.justification: Provides context on common vendor requirements for liability limitations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp needs to be aware of these common vendor requests and prepare its negotiation strategy.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will typically seek to limit their liability down the chain to the end customer.

content.text: It is not unusual for the software vendors to also require that we will also expressly limit the vendors liability in our end customer contract by in e.g. adding following provisions to our end customer contract: “[XYZ] Corporation disclaims all warranties, whether express or implied. [XYX] Corporation shall have no liability towards the [Customer] “.

content.verbatim_text: In the majority of the cases, Zebracorp is not able to agree to such requests to modify our customer contracts. This is because, not all of our customer contracts contain such provisions and it is often next to impossible to amend our contract with our end customers merely to include certain language requested by an individual software vendor. The fact is that Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with our customers, and those contracts cannot be modified to suit the individual needs of each our vendor.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp generally cannot agree to modify its customer contracts to include vendor-specific liability limitations due to existing frame contracts and the impracticality of individual amendments.
content.expert_insight: This is a firm 'no' from Zebracorp due to operational and contractual realities. Modifying master frame agreements for every vendor is unfeasible. This position must be clearly communicated.
content.conditions: When vendors request modification of Zebracorp's customer contracts to limit vendor liability.
content.justification: Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with customers that cannot be modified for individual vendor needs, and not all customer contracts contain such provisions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must firmly resist these requests to maintain the integrity and manageability of its customer contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that Zebracorp's existing contractual framework with its customers limits its ability to make such modifications.

The fact is that Zebracorp has existing frame contracts with our customers, and those contracts cannot be modified to suit the individual needs of each our vendor.

content.verbatim_text: If this requirement cannot be negotiated away, we can as a compromise, agree to inform our end customer of these limitations in writing in lieu of including these limitations in the agreement.

content.justification: To provide a compromise when direct contract modification is not possible.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this compromise to satisfy vendor requests while preserving its customer contract structure, but must ensure a reliable process for written notification.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may accept this as a secondary measure to ensure end customers are aware of liability limitations.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances our licensors will ask that Zebracorp assumes liability for any breach of the sublicense terms and restrictions by its customers. This is not something that we can accept. The customers are independent third parties and Zebracorp cannot control the actions of its customers or give any guarantees of behalf of such parties.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp cannot accept liability for its customers' breaches of sublicense terms, as customers are independent third parties whose actions Zebracorp cannot control or guarantee.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental risk management principle. Zebracorp cannot be held responsible for the independent actions of its customers. This position should be non-negotiable.

content.justification: Customers are independent third parties whose actions Zebracorp cannot control or guarantee.

This is not something that we can accept. The customers are independent third parties and Zebracorp cannot control the actions of its customers or give any guarantees of behalf of such parties.

content.verbatim_text: At best, we can contractually bind the customers to certain license terms and restrictions and report any violations to our licensor.
content.plain_text: At most, Zebracorp can contractually bind customers to license terms and report violations to the licensor.
content.expert_insight: This defines the realistic limit of Zebracorp's control and responsibility over its end customers, setting the stage for acceptable compromise language.
content.justification: Clarifies the extent of Zebracorp's ability to manage customer compliance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should focus on robust contractual terms with its customers and efficient reporting mechanisms for licensors.

content.verbatim_text: In the event of such requests, we can propose the below alternative wording instead: “If [Zebracorp] becomes aware of any material breach of any of the license terms and restrictions by its [Customer], [Zebracorp] shall promptly notify the [Licensor] thereof. In the event of the occurrence of any such material breach, the [Parties] shall consult in good faith on the next steps with respect to such breach and enforcement of such license restrictions”.
content.plain_text: As an alternative, Zebracorp can propose wording where it promptly notifies the licensor of any material customer breach and both parties consult in good faith on next steps for enforcement.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong, collaborative compromise. It places an obligation on Zebracorp to monitor and report, and commits both parties to a good-faith resolution process, without Zebracorp assuming direct liability.
content.justification: Provides an alternative wording for managing customer breaches without Zebracorp assuming direct liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this to manage licensor expectations and demonstrate commitment to IP protection while protecting itself from undue liability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers would likely find this a reasonable and collaborative approach to addressing customer breaches.

In the event of the occurrence of any such material breach, the [Parties] shall consult in good faith on the next steps with respect to such breach and enforcement of such license restrictions”.

content.verbatim_text: Beneficiaries of license. Note that all of the license rights should extend to the Zebracorp Group as a whole. The Zebracorp entity that signs the contract is not necessarily the same as the ordering Zebracorp entity. Moreover, the actual distribution and sublicensing or usage of the licensed products may be by a local Zebracorp entity as opposed to the entity that entered into the contract with the licensor. In each case the affiliates of Zebracorp should obtain the same rights as the signing Zebracorp entity.
content.plain_text: All license rights must extend to the entire Zebracorp Group, ensuring that affiliates obtain the same rights as the signing entity, regardless of which Zebracorp entity orders, distributes, sublicenses, or uses the products.
content.expert_insight: This is fundamental for a multinational corporation like Zebracorp. Without group-wide rights, individual entities would be operating without proper licenses, leading to potential infringement claims. The 'signing entity' vs 'using entity' distinction is critical.
content.conditions: For all license agreements.
content.justification: To ensure all relevant Zebracorp entities have necessary rights for operation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure all license agreements explicitly grant rights to its entire Group, including affiliates, to support its global operational structure.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be aware that Zebracorp will require group-wide licensing, which may impact pricing or scope.

The Zebracorp entity that signs the contract is not necessarily the same as the ordering Zebracorp entity. Moreover, the actual distribution and sublicensing or usage of the licensed products may be by a local Zebracorp entity as opposed to the entity that entered into the contract with the licensor. In each case the affiliates of Zebracorp should obtain the same rights as the signing Zebracorp entity.

content.expert_insight: This demonstrates Zebracorp's standard practice and preferred language for extending rights to its group and contractors.
content.justification: Provides an example of template language for including affiliates and contractors.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should use this template language as a starting point for negotiations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will encounter this language in Zebracorp's template agreements.

content.text: The above is reflected in the provisions found in our inlicensing agreement templates that contain the following language: “Any license granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall include Affiliates and contractor(s) of [Licensee]”.

content.verbatim_text: Where needed, we can remove some of the ambiguity surrounding the extent of the use by our contractors and revise this to read in e.g. as follows: “Any licenses granted to the [Licensee] shall also include the Affiliates of the [Licensee]. Any licenses granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall also extend to the subcontractors of [Licensee], but solely to the extent required for the purpose of enabling such subcontractors to perform work or provide services for [Licensee] (and its Affiliates) in support of this [Agreement], and not for the benefit of any third parties or for such subcontractor’s own benefit, and only while such subcontractors are providing such services to [Licensee] (and its Affiliates). For clarity, [Licensee] may not grant to its Affiliates and subcontractors any greater rights than [Licensee] has obtained from [Licensor]”.
content.plain_text: To clarify contractor use, licenses can be extended to affiliates and subcontractors, but strictly for performing work/services for Zebracorp (and its affiliates) in support of the agreement, not for third-party or subcontractor's own benefit, and only while providing such services. Affiliates and subcontractors cannot be granted greater rights than Zebracorp obtained.
content.expert_insight: This detailed language provides important guardrails for contractor use. It ensures that contractors are only using the software for Zebracorp's benefit and within the scope of the primary license, mitigating risks for both Zebracorp and the licensor.
content.justification: To clarify and limit the extent of use by contractors and subcontractors.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should adopt this more precise language to clearly define the scope of contractor/subcontractor use, protecting itself and reassuring licensors.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will likely appreciate this detailed and protective language for contractor/subcontractor use.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Where needed, we can remove some of the ambiguity surrounding the extent of the use by our contractors and revise this to read in e.g. as follows: “Any licenses granted to the [Licensee] shall also include the Affiliates of the [Licensee]. Any licenses granted to [Licensee] under this [Agreement] shall also extend to the subcontractors of [Licensee], but solely to the extent required for the purpose of enabling such subcontractors to perform work or provide services for [Licensee] (and its Affiliates) in support of this [Agreement], and not for the benefit of any third parties or for such subcontractor’s own benefit, and only while such subcontractors are providing such services to [Licensee] (and its Affiliates). For clarity, [Licensee] may not grant to its Affiliates and subcontractors any greater rights than [Licensee] has obtained from [Licensor]”.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp Preferred Position. The license grant should give Zebracorp the necessary rights to each conceivable use of the licensed software/technology. Note that this is not necessarily reflected in the boilerplate license grants found in Zebracorp procurement contract templates, but those should be modified to reflect the actual needs for each case in hand. In direct procurement contracts, it is important to make sure that the licenses also give Zebracorp the right to distribute/sublicense to its end customers and that such end customers obtain perpetual licenses (save where the license is specifically tied to a certain time frame).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred position is to secure all conceivable rights for its use of licensed software/technology. Boilerplate templates should be customized for specific needs. In direct procurement, ensuring rights to distribute/sublicense to end customers, with perpetual sublicenses (unless time-limited), is crucial.
content.expert_insight: This summarizes Zebracorp's overarching strategy: comprehensive rights, tailored contracts, and critical downstream rights. It emphasizes that templates are starting points, not definitive solutions, and that distribution/sublicensing with perpetual rights for end customers is non-negotiable for its business model.
content.conditions: For all license grants and direct procurement contracts.
content.justification: To ensure Zebracorp has all necessary rights for its business operations and to meet end-customer expectations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must proactively define and negotiate for all required rights, customizing templates and prioritizing distribution/sublicensing with perpetual end-customer licenses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to seek broad, specific rights tailored to its business, especially concerning distribution and perpetual sublicenses for end customers.
